revision.text:
'''Mental Management''' explores, describes and studies the mental processes in their diversity. This [[psychology]] of [[cognitive psychology|cognitive]] [[consciousness]] was elaborated by [[Antoine de la Garanderie]] from the analysis of [[mental habit]]s of numerous subjects.
== History ==
The '''Mental Management''' theory was elaborated from numerous [[pedagogical dialogue]]s since the 1970s.
It is linked to several previous theories, including the works on [[introspection]] by [[Jean Martin Charcot]], [[Alfred Binet]], [[Marie François Pierre Gontier de Biran|Maine de Biran]], the German school of [[History of psychology#Würzburg School|Würzburg]] ([[Henry Jackson Watt|Watt]], {{ill|August Messer|lt=Messer|de}}, [[Karl Bühler|Bühler]]) and [[Albert Burloud]], who was [[Antoine de la Garanderie]]'s professor.
== Theory ==
The fundamental concepts of '''Mental Management''' are [[evocation]] and [[mental project]].
Although it doesn't have a [[Phenomenology (psychology)|phenomenological]] goal, '''Mental Management''' is based on several concepts of characterization of evocation : * the ''nature'' (or ''language'') of the evocation : visual, auditive, verbal, etc. * the ''parameters'' used : concrete (P1), codes (P2), logical links (P3) or new links (P4) * the ''coding'' : first or third person * the ''place of meaning'' : spatial
a great application is the game of capsule, likely played in the 6th floor of the X building{{explain|date=April 2016}}
Aside this Mental management is used to organize therapeutical wealth in business organisation,
and also to have a clear Mind for working and to strengthen working methods for the social problems at work.
<!-- These should not be presetn if they remain empty !!! == Means == == Objectives == == Applications == game of capsule -->
== External links ==
<!-- [[Category:Psychology]] too general --> <!-- [[Category:Philosophy]] too general --> <!-- [[Category:Phenomenology]] too general --> [[Category:Cognitive science]] [[Category:Pedagogy]]
{{cognitive-psych-stub}}

{{Orphan|date=May 2014}} Professor Michael (Mike) Rosenak (December 23, 1932 – May 14, 2013) was an Israeli [[philosopher]] of Jewish education. He was Mandel Professor of Jewish Education at The Hebrew University in Jerusalem. == Biography == Michael Rosenak was born in Germany but he grew up in the United States.{{cite web|last=Lockshin|first=Martin|title=Posthumous essay collection sheds light on Jewish identity |url= http://www.cjnews.com/books-and-authors/posthumous-essay-collection-sheds-light-jewish-identity|work=Canadian Jewish News|accessdate=10 April 2014}} He graduated [[Yeshiva University]]. He emigrated to Israel in 1958. In the 1960s, he taught a popular course at Hebrew University's program for overseas students, "Basic issues in contemporary Jewish life."{{cite book|last=Zuroff|first=Efraim|title=Operation Last Chance|date=2009|publisher=Macmillan|page=21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tT6dG3g5ZFAC&lpg=PA21&dq=michael%20rosenak&pg=PA21#v=onepage&q=michael%20rosenak&f=false|isbn=9780230101388}} He held various positions during his academic life, before becoming a full professor at the Melton Centre, and was also noted for his involvement in hands-on educational institutions, such as Kiryat Moriah (World Zionist Organization), the Pardes Institute, the development of the curriculum for the Independent Jewish Day School in London, the Mandel Institute, and many prestigious institutions of Jewish education around the world. == Education ==
Michael Rosenak had graduated at Yeshiva University (New York): B.A. (sociology) and B.R.E. (Bachelor of Religious Education) (1954). Columbia University (New York), M.A. History (1957). Hebrew University (Jerusalem), PhD, in Education (1976). == Teaching and academic work ==
Michael Rosenak was a Mandel Professor of Jewish Education at the Hebrew University; Head of Education Studies at “The Jerusalem Fellows”, a division of The Mandel School for Educational Leadership that deals specifically with Jewish educational leadership outside Israel; Lecturer and author. In his field, the Philosophy of Education, Michael Rosenak had concentrated on issues of faith and religion in education, specially in the field of Jewish education, dealing with such matters as the challenge of indoctrination of religious education, value education and the tension between normative and deliberative modes of teaching. He had written on the dialectic relationship between commitment and openness, and on the status of absolute values in democratic society as well as issues of Jewish community and identity. His work has been intended to develop theoretical growing for religious faith that is in authentic dialogue with modernity and democracy, and to build philosophical and educational foundations for communities that wish to foster broad cognitive perspectives in young people. == Professional engagement ==
Before turning to academic pursuits, Michael Rosenak taught in high schools, and in the framework of educational programs for young people from abroad (i.e., outside Israel). In the 1960s, he taught a popular course at Hebrew University's program for overseas students, "Basic issues in contemporary Jewish life."[2] Michael Rosenak was also noted for his involvement in hands-on educational institutions, such as Kiryat Moriah (World Zionist Organization), the Pardes Institute, the development of the curriculum for the Independent Jewish Day School in London and many prestigious institutions of Jewish education around the world. Michael Rosenak had lectured widely, specially in Jewish communities around the world on educational issues that affect the quality, coherence and cogency of Jewish life. Michael Rosenak had been a board member of The Melitz Institute for Informal Education, Jerusalem; serve on the board of the Center for the Study of Jewish Educational Thought of the Lifshitz College, Jerusalem. He was a member of the Holocaust Commission of The Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture, New York and had served on the academic advisory board of the Yad Vashem school in Holocaust studies. Michael Rosenak was on the steering committee of the Israeli Society for Research in Jewish Education and as act academic advisor for the Florence Melton Mini – School project for Israel. == Academic teaching abroad ==
Michael Rosenak had taught in diverse colleges and universities as Stanford University (School of Education); York University, Toronto, Ontario; The Jewish Theological Seminary of America, New York; The Cleveland College of Jewish Studies, Cleveland, Ohio. == Awards and honors ==
Michael Rosenak had been honored by: The Jewish Theological Seminary of America (1997) - an honorary doctorate. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem - the Samuel Rothberg Prize in Jewish Education (2001). The Hebrew Union College - an honorary doctorate (2003). Yeshivah University (New York) - an honorary doctorate (2008). == Books and articles ==
* Michael Rosenak. 1986. Teaching Jewish Values: A Conceptual Guide. Jerusalem: The Melton Centre, The Hebrew University. (Spanish edition published by the Melton Centre in 1987; Russian edition published by The Joint Distribution Committee in Jerusalem, 1995). * Michael Rosenak. 1987. [https://books.google.com/books?id=q6D1GFBSptcC&printsec=frontcover&hl=iw&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false Commandments and Concerns: Jewish Religious Education] in Secular Society. Philadelphia: Jewish Publication Society. * Michael Rosenak. 1995. [https://books.google.com/books?id=7YOLxWckcOsC&printsec=frontcover&hl=iw&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false Roads to the Palace: Jewish Texts and Teaching]. Providence, Oxford and London: Berghahn Books for the Institute of Education, University of London. * Michael Rosenak. 2001. Tree of Life, Tree of Knowledge, Boulder, Colorado: Westview.
* מיכאל רוזנק, '''צריך עיון: בין מסורת ומודרנה בחינוך היהודי''', ירושלים: [[הוצאת מאגנס]] תשס"ג * Michael Rosenak, Covenant and Community JTSA PRESS, 2013 * Michael Rosenak, “Religious Jewish Education and the Holocaust: the theological Dimension,” Philosophia (Department of Philosophy, Bar- Ilan University, Vol.30. Nos. 1-4, 2002). * Michael Rosenak, “Corporal Punishment in Jewish education: a philosophic–educational exploration,” Studies in Contemporary Jewry, Hebrew University, 2002). * Michael Rosenak, “Rabbi Eliyahu E. Dessler´s Philosophy of Ultra-Orthodox Education” Festschrift in Honor of Professor Joseph Lukinsky, The Jewish Theological Seminary, 2002. * Michael Rosenak, “The Contemporary Ideal of ´An Educated Public´: Mission Impossible?” Panim: Quarterly for Society, Education and Culture, Tel Aviv, Winter 2001 (Hebrew). * Michael Rosenak, “Foci of Religious Extremism: Educational Dimensions,” Hagut: Jewish educational thought, Vol. I, Jerusalem, Center for Jewish Educational Thought, 1998. (Hebrew). * Michael Rosenak, “Between Texts and Contexts: How May Tomorrow’s Jewish Education be Different?” in Creating the Jewish Future (edited by Michael Brown and Bernard Lightman) (Walter Creek, London, New Delhi: Altamira Press, 1999.). * Michael Rosenak, Teaching Israel: Basic Issues and Philosophical Guidelines, (monograph) (with Arnold Eisen) (Jerusalem: the CRB Foundation. Charles Bronfman Center for the Israel Experience, 1997). * Michael Rosenak, “Between Autonomy and Authority in Religious Education”, Between Authority and Autonomy in Jewish Tradition (edited by Avi Sagi and Zeev Safrai) (Tel Aviv: Hakibbutz Hameuhad Publishers, 1997) (Hebrew). * Michael Rosenak, “Jewish education and Jewish Studies”, Jewish Studies Vol. 36 (Jerusalem: World Union of Jewish Studies, 1996). * Michael Rosenak, “Jewish Fundamentalism in Israeli education,” (Vol.2) Fundamentalisms and Society: reclaiming the sciences, the family and education (edited by Martin E. Marty and R. Scott Appleby (Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press, 1993). * Michael Rosenak, “Commitment and Non-Commitment in Jewish Value Education,” Studies in Jewish Education, Vol. 6 (Jerusalem: The Magnes Press, 1992). * Michael Rosenak, “Towards a Curriculum for the Modern Orthodox School”, Orthodoxy Confronts Modernity (edited by Jonathan Sacks) (Hoboken, N.J., Ktav Publishing House, Inc., 1991). * Michael Rosenak's website: '''http://hamutallawrence.wix.com/rosenak''' == References == {{reflist}} * Wikipedia Academia references [https://wikipedia.academia.edu/MichaelRosenak] * "Further Reading" (With short biography, the Mandel Institute website) [http://mandel.mli.org.il/Visions/Library/Pages/Michael+Rosenak+Educated+Jews.htm] * Short obituary and references, H-Net [http://h-net.msu.edu/cgi-bin/logbrowse.pl?trx=vx&list=H-Judaic&month=1305&msg=RFbDD4R/090okRodabwDeQ] {{DEFAULTSORT:Rosenak, Michael}} [[Category:1932 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:Israeli philosophers]] [[Category:Jewish philosophers]] [[Category:Philosophers of education]]

revision.text:
{{update|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox organization | name = National Association of School Psychologists | image = | image_border = | size = 200 px | caption = | formation = 1969 | type = | headquarters = [[Bethesda, Maryland]] | location = [[United States]] | language = | leader_title = Executive Director | leader_name = Kathleen Minke | key_people = | key_name = | website = http://www.nasponline.org/ }}
The '''National Association of School Psychologists''' ('''NASP''') is the major national [[Professional association|professional organization]] for [[School psychology|school psychologists]] in the [[United States]]. Its [[Mission statement|stated mission]] is to "represent and support school psychology through leadership to enhance the [[mental health]] and educational competence of all children." The vision of NASP is that all children and youth access the learning, behavior, and mental health support needed to thrive in school, at home, and throughout life. The four main purpose of this organization is "a) to actively promote the interests of school psychology; b) to advance the standards of the profession; c) to help secure the conditions necessary to the greatest effectiveness of its practice; and d) to serve the mental health and educational interest of all children and youth" <ref>{{cite web |title=History of the National Association of School Psychologists: The First Decade |url=http://www.nasponline.org/publications/periodicals/spr/volume-8/volume-8-issue-2/history-of-the-national-association-of-school-psychologists-the-first-decade |website=National Association of School Psychologists (NASP) |accessdate=1 December 2018 |language=en}}</ref>.
NASP provides standards for ethics and practice, and approves graduate training programs that sufficiently adhere to its training guidelines. NASP is a constituent member of the [[National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education]] (NCATE) and although NCATE accredits units (such as [[School of education|colleges of education]]), not programs, it does provide "national recognition" status to NASP-approved programs located in units accredited by NCATE.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nasponline.org/certification/NASPapproved.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-10-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060305032505/http://www.nasponline.org/certification/NASPapproved.html |archivedate=2006-03-05 |df= }}</ref>
The organization also offers an opportunity for those who have successfully completed their graduate coursework, participated in a 1200-hour internship with at least 600 hours in a school setting, and received a score of at least 660 on the School Psychologist Praxis II Examination to apply for [[National Certification in School Psychology]].
While the [[American Psychological Association]] (APA) serves similar purposes through Division 16,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiana.edu/~div16/|title=Indiana University Bloomington|website=Indiana University Bloomington}}</ref> one way that NASP differs fundamentally from the APA is in that it officially recognizes the [[specialist degree]] as the entry-level degree for the field, as opposed to the [[Doctorate|doctoral degree]]. The two organizations, however, are more complementary than competing. Many view NASP as the governing body for sub-doctoral school psychologists and the APA as the governing body for doctoral-level school psychologists, although there are many doctoral-level school psychologists who belong to NASP. Further, NASP approval of graduate programs does not compete with APA accreditation; the APA does not accredit non-doctoral programs,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apa.org/ed/accreditation/schoolpsy.html|title=APA-Accredited Programs|website=apa.org}}</ref> and NASP will more quickly approve programs that have already been APA-accredited.<ref>http://www.nasponline.org/certification/APA_programs.html</ref>
The National Association of School Psychologists distributes two journals: ''School Psychology Review'', which is the second-largest psychology academic journal and includes research and theory related to school psychology, and ''School Psychology Forum: Research in Practice'', an electronic publication. NASP also publishes ''Communiqué'', which is the official newspaper of NASP, covering news, events, innovative practices, legislative developments, and other topics relevant to the field.
'''
=== History ===
The National Association of School Psychologists was created on March 15, 1969 during a two-day national conference in St. Louis. NASP is the world's largest organization to serve the interests of school psychologists exclusively. NASP is govern by nationally elected officers and state-elected representatives to the NASP's primary legislative body, NASP Delegates Assembly. There are two delegate representatives in each of its four region with the executive council consisting of the elected officers and program managers. Including committee members, editors, etc. within the program manager areas, the governing body exceeds 200 individuals. The central office facilities is located in Bethesda, Maryland, where the policies and business of NASP are implemented <ref>{{cite book |last1=Fagan |first1=Thomas |last2=Wise |first2=Paula |title=School psychology : past, present, and future |publisher=National Association of School Psychologists |isbn=978-0932955-71-5 |edition=3rd}}</ref>.
; '''2018/2019: NASP Executive Council'''
*NASP President — Lisa Kelly- Vance *President-Elect — Leslie Z. Paige *Past President — John Kelly *Secretary — Wendy Price *Treasurer — Misty Lay
NASP provides a year-round membership and access to evidence-based resources, periodicals exploring the most current issues, and networking opportunities. There are different rates and categories offered to become a member such as regular member, student member, retired member, international member, and so forth. The memberships run from July 1-June 30. NASP offers a Find-A-Mentor Program where an individual can choose to become a mentor or find a mentor. This program provides support at all levels of professional growth and development. NASP also offers awards, grants, and scholarships <ref>{{cite web |title=Find-a-Mentor Program |url=http://www.nasponline.org/membership-and-community/get-involved/find-a-mentor-program |website=National Association of School Psychologists (NASP) |accessdate=1 December 2018 |language=en}}</ref>.
NASP Practice Model represents NASP's official policy regarding the delivery of school psychological services. The NASP Practice Model is one of the four major of parts of Professional Standards NASP 2010 and creates flexibility for agencies and professionals to develop policies and procedures that meet local needs, while also providing sufficient specificity to ensure appropriate, comprehensive service provision. The NASP Practice Model consists of two parts: Professional Practices and Organizational Principles.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.nasponline.org www.nasponline.org] — Official site *[http://www.nasponline.org/publications/spr/index.aspx School Psychology Review] *[http://www.nasponline.org/publications/cq/index.aspx Communiqué] *[http://www.indiana.edu/~div16 Division 16 of the American Psychological Association]
[[Category:Psychology-related professional associations]] [[Category:Education-related professional associations]] [[Category:Psychology organizations based in the United States]]

revision.text:
From 2004, the '''New Zealand Scholarship''' is a [[New Zealand]] secondary school award gained at the end of Year 13, and provides financial support for study at a New Zealand university. <!-- It replaces the scholarships from the University Entrance, Bursaries and Scholarships Examinations ("UEBS") which were awarded for the last time in 2003. -->It is intended for the top students of [[National Certificate of Educational Achievement|NCEA]] Level 3, the main secondary school leaving qualification.
==About== The first scholarship examination by the University of New Zealand was held in May 1872.<ref>{{cite book | last = Beaglehole | first = J. C. | authorlink = John Cawte Beaglehole | title = The University of New Zealand: A historical study | year = 1937 | publisher = New Zealand Council for Educational Research | id = {{LCC|LG735.B365}} | pages = 85 | chapter = | quote = … there were already thirty-five entries for the first scholarship examination in May 1872…}}</ref><ref name="par70">{{cite book | last = Parton | first = Hugh | title = The University of New Zealand | year = 1979 | publisher = University Grants Committee, New Zealand | isbn = 0-19-647973-8 | pages = 98 | quote = The first scholarship examination was held in May 1872…}}</ref> After 1962, scholarships were awarded by the Universities Entrance Board. The [[New Zealand Qualifications Authority]] took over the work of the Universities Entrance Board in 1991.
From 1989 to 2003 scholarships were awarded to the top 3-4% of [[New Zealand University Bursary|Bursary]] students. In response to the removal of separate scholarship examinations a group of teachers set up their own scholarship exam, later becoming the [[New Zealand Educational Scholarships Trust]] (NZEST).[https://web.archive.org/web/20051228142034/http://nzest.ac.nz/about.html]
A "NCEA Level 4" qualification was proposed in the 1998 Cabinet paper "Qualifications for Young People Aged 16 to 19 Years" and the discussions that ensued concluded that there be an external examination and that scholarships be awarded. [https://web.archive.org/web/20060630090835/http://www.nzqa.govt.nz/scholarship/background.html] New Zealand Scholarship exams started in 2004. NZEST stopped its examinations and now provides financial assistance for students studying at NZ universities.
The 2004 examinations, in line with the NCEA, were criterion-referenced and produced some unexpected results distributions. Several reviews of the award and a media and political debate followed. The Scholarship examination was largely revamped. Scholarships in 2005 were awarded to the top three per cent of NCEA Level 3 candidates in the subject, given that examiners are satisfied a worthy standard has been met. Monetary awards were restructured and credit value was removed from the examinations.
==Assessment== The Scholarship is awarded by standards-based three-hour external examinations, which are mostly written exams. The grades are ''No Award'', ''Scholarship'' and ''Outstanding Scholarship''. [https://web.archive.org/web/20070926224033/http://www.nzqa.govt.nz/scholarship/results-subject.html Example of result table at NZQA]
The 2004 examination of the New Zealand Scholarship by the [[New Zealand Qualifications Authority]] was marred by controversy, most notably the irregular pass rates (e.g. 0.9% pass rate for Biology 2004). The head of the Authority later resigned over this and allied issues.
==Monetary Awards== {{Refimprove|date=November 2011}}
:''All monetary values are in the [[New Zealand dollar]]. The monetary awards are tenable at any New Zealand [[university]], and all except single subject awards last for three years as long as a 'B' average is maintained. Candidates must gain at least three scholarships to be eligible for the Scholarship, Outstanding and Premier awards. All candidates are eligible for only one of the following monetary awards, except that up to two single subject awards can be awarded to a candidate, and a winner of a Top Subject Scholar Award who also passes a second scholarship subject is eligible for the additional $500 award.
*The ''Premier Award'' is awarded to the top five to ten candidates who gain three or more scholarship subjects with at least three at outstanding level, and is worth $10,000 per year for three years. *An ''Outstanding Scholar Award'' is awarded to the top 40 to 60 candidates (usually around the top 0.3% of the number of Level 3 students sitting the subject, but more for the less common subjects) who gain three scholarship subjects with two at outstanding level or gain more than three scholarship subjects with at least one at outstanding level, and is worth $5,000 per year for three years. *A ''Scholarship Award'' is awarded to all candidates who gain three or more scholarship subjects, and is worth $2,000 per year for three years. *A ''Top Subject Scholar Award''' is awarded to candidates who are top of a subject, and did not receive one of the above prizes. It is worth $2,000 per year for three years. *A single subject award is awarded to candidates who gain one or two scholarship subjects and did not top the subject(s). It is worth $500 per subject for one year only.
==References== <references/>
==See also== *[[New Zealand Qualifications Authority]] ([http://www.nzqa.govt.nz website]) (awarding body) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20041202070334/http://nzest.ac.nz/ New Zealand Educational Scholarships Trust] *[http://www.nzqa.govt.nz/qualifications/ssq/scholarship/index.html New Zealand Scholarship website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20031218092114/http://www.nzqa.govt.nz/news/info/awards04.html Press release 15 December 2003 detailing prizes] *[http://sclrship.com/category/country/new-zealand-scholarships List of New Zealand's Scholarships]
[[Category:Education in New Zealand]] [[Category:Student financial aid]]

revision.text:
{{notability|1=Products|date=February 2018}}
'''Pass.ng''' is a self-testing online platform in Nigeria which allows users to practice for national exams through interactive modules.<ref>{{cite web|title=Q&A: SAMSON ABIOYE, CEO AND CO-FOUNDER, PASS.NG|url=http://innovation-village.com/qa-samson-abioye-ceo-and-co-founder-pass-ng/|publisher=innovation-village.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Startups|url=http://440.ng/startups/|website=440|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref><ref name="aa">{{cite web|title=The Evolution of a Startup Helping Students Hack Standardized Tests: Samson Abioye on Pass.ng {{!}} TechCabal|url=http://techcabal.com/2015/07/15/the-evolution-of-a-startup-helping-students-hack-standardized-tests-samson-abioye-on-pass-ng/|publisher=techcabal.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> Founded in 2012 as Jamb-cbt.com, It won the airtel's ''Catapult-a-Startup'',<ref>{{cite web|title=TELECOMAirtel Empowers Seven Startups|url=http://nigeriacommunicationsweek.com.ng/airtel-empowers-seven-startups/|website=nigeriacommunicationsweek|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> the ''AAI pitch-fest competition''<ref>{{cite web|title=AAI PitchFest Video testimonial|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BcGl1i3tQ2I|website=youtube|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> and the ''West Africa Mobile Awards (WAMAS)'' in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pass.ng, Genii Games, Jason Njoku among WAMAS winners|url=http://disrupt-africa.com/2016/04/pass-ng-genii-games-jason-njoku-among-wamas-winners/|publisher=disrupt-africa.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> It also got an endorsement from [[Joint Admissions and Matriculation Board]] in 2015.
==Background== In an interview with Outliers Magazine, [[Samson Abioye]] said he got the idea for pass.ng after learning that over 70% of those who sit for national exams fail in [[Nigeria]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Outliers Magazine interview with the founders of Pass.ng|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=saJ2bjDHvRk|publisher=youtube.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> He thereafter pitched the idea to his fellow undergraduates during their Industrial Training program with the ICT Unit of [[Ladoke Akintola University]]. He was joined by Abayomi Akanji, Imole Oluyemi and Joshua Adebagbo and they registered the new startup as Pass.ng. Abayomi went on to become the Head of mobile development and, Imole was the Product Design Lead, Joshua the Chief technology officer and Abioye Samson the [[Chief executive officer]].<ref>{{cite web|title=440.NG Investor Day 2014 - Pass Pitch|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UTZ6nuBcrRA|website=youtube|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
==Business model== Pass.ng functions on a [[freemium]] pricing model. A limited amount of preparatory questions can be attempted for free, after which further usage requires loading a recharge card of the intended subscription price. During the initial stage, users had to go to the bank to pay the amount of their intended subscription (which most times is very little). The process was said to be tedious, time wasting and reportedly drove a lot of intending paying subscribers away. A model of sending the recharge card of the intended subscription was also developed but also wasn't helpful either as the founders got loads of recharges without knowing what to do with them. They have since decided to work with some of Nigerians telecom agent on a model of allowing the user to recharge on their lines the amount they wish to subscribe which will be deducted by the telcoms themselves and a percentage paid to pass.<ref name="aa" />
==Awards and recognition==
* Pass.ng has been endorsed by the exam conducting body - [[Joint Admissions and Matriculation Board]] in 2015. * Pass.ng won the [[Bharti Airtel|Airtel]] Catapult-a-Startup entrepreneurship development program. This included a cash prize of 1 million [[Nigerian naira|naira]] and promotion opportunity from Airtel. * Pass.ng is listed as a service on Airtel's website.<ref>{{cite web|title=pass.ng|url=http://www.africa.airtel.com/wps/wcm/connect/africarevamp/Nigeria/Home/personal/Internet/Services/pass#|website=africa.airtel|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> * Pass.ng won the 2015 edition of the AAI pitch-fest competition. * Pass.ng was among the 2016 winners of the West Africa Mobile Awards (WAMAS).
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox research institute |name = Research Institute of Molecular Pathology (IMP) |image = [[File:Entrance-area.jpg|250px]] |established = 1985 |head_label = Director |head = [[Jan-Michael Peters]] (science); Harald Isemann (administration) |type = {{ublist|class=nowrap |[[Basic research|Basic]] {{smaller|(non-clinical)}} |[[Life sciences]]}} |research_field = {{ublist|class=nowrap |[[Molecular and Cellular Biology]]| [[Structural Biology|Structural biology and biochemistry]] |[[Gene expression]] and [[chromosome|chromosome biology]] |[[Stem cell biology]] and [[developmental biology|development]] |[[Immunology]] and [[cancer]] | [[Neuroscience]]}} |faculty = 15 |staff = 250 |budget = |endowment = |debt = |city = [[Vienna]] |state = [[Austria]] |address = Campus-Vienna-Biocenter 1, 1030 Vienna, Austria |website = {{url|www.imp.ac.at}} }}
The '''Research Institute of Molecular Pathology (IMP)''' is a biomedical research center, which conducts curiosity-driven [[basic research]] in the [[molecular biology|molecular]] [[life sciences]].
The IMP is located at the [[Vienna Biocenter]] in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]]. The institute employs around 250 people from 36 nations, of which approximately 200 are scientists.{{cn|date=February 2018}} The working language at the IMP is English. The IMP was established in 1985 and is funded by the pharmaceutical company [[Boehringer Ingelheim]] and research grants.<ref name="boehringer-ingelheim.com">{{cite web | title=The Research Institute of Molecular Pathology | website=boehringer-ingelheim.com | url=https://www.boehringer-ingelheim.com/research-development/research-institute-molecular-pathology/research-institute-molecular-pathology | access-date=2018-02-18}}</ref>
==Research== [[File:IMP-lab.jpg|thumb|Laboratory at the IMP. Up to three research groups share a lab to support communication and exchange.]] IMP comprises 15 independent research groups performing [[basic research|basic]] biological research across the following areas:<ref name="IMPResearch">{{cite web | title=Main Research Areas | website=The Research Institute of Molecular Pathology | url=https://www.imp.ac.at/research/research-areas/ | access-date=2018-02-18}}</ref> * [[molecular biology|molecular]] and [[cell biology|cellular biology]]; * [[structural biology]] and [[biochemistry]]; * [[gene expression]] and [[chromosome]] biology; * [[stem cell]] biology and [[developmental biology|development]]; * [[immunology]] and [[cancer]]; * [[neuroscience]].
===Publications, awards and honours=== Scientists at the IMP publish 60 to 90 papers in international peer-review journals per year: between 1985 and 2017, more than 2,000 research papers were published. 93 patents were filed based on discoveries made at the institute since 1985. IMP faculty was awarded 16 [[European Research Council|ERC Grants]] since the establishment of this grant scheme in 2007. Four IMP faculty members received [[Wittgenstein-Preis|Wittgenstein Awards]] since 1996. About one third of the faculty are elected members of [[European Molecular Biology Organization|EMBO]].<ref name="IMPHistory" /> In 2017, [[Kim Nasmyth]] received the [[Breakthrough Prize]] in life sciences for work on [[cohesin]] that he had done at the IMP. <ref>https://www.imp.ac.at/news/detail/article/breakthrough-prize-awarded-to-kim-nasmyth/</ref>
===Facilities=== IMP maintains a suite of in-house facilities, maintained in cooperation with IMBA, that provide support and scientific services to the scientists at IMP.<ref name="CoresIMP">{{cite web | title=Welcome to Core Facilities | website=IMP | url=http://cores.imp.ac.at/ | access-date=2018-02-18}}</ref> In addition, the four research institutes of the Vienna Biocenter maintain a number of shared services jointly called "VBC Core Facilities" (VBCF). The services offered are available to all VBC scientists including IMP staff.<ref name="VBCF 2018">{{cite web | title=VBCF | website=VBCF | date=2018-02-01 | url=http://www.vbcf.ac.at/home/ | access-date=2018-02-18}}</ref>
==History== The establishment of the IMP was a joint venture by [[Boehringer Ingelheim]] and [[Genentech]] and initiated in 1985. Under the directorship of [[Max Birnstiel]], the first institute building was opened in 1988.
In 1992, three institutes of the faculties of science and medicine of the [[University of Vienna]] moved into a nearby building, today's [[Max F. Perutz Laboratories]] (MFPL). This created the basis for referring to the area as the "Vienna Biocenter" (VBC).
In 1993, Boehringer Ingelheim took over the IMP shares of Genentech. Following Max Birnstiel's retirement in 1997, [[Kim Nasmyth]] became scientific director.
In 2006, two institutes of the Austrian Academy of Sciences were opened in the vicinity of the IMP: the [[Institute of Molecular Biotechnology]] (IMBA) and the [[Gregor Mendel Institute]] (GMI). The three institutes cooperate closely by maintaining shared facilities. In the same year, [[Barry Dickson]] became the IMP's scientific director.
Since 2013, [[Jan-Michael Peters]] is scientific director of the IMP. In late 2016, the IMP moved into its new building, which was formally opened on 1 March 2017.<ref name="IMPHistory">{{cite web | title=History | website=The Research Institute of Molecular Pathology | url=https://www.imp.ac.at/about/history/ | access-date=2018-02-18}}</ref>
==PhD program== The "VBC PhD Programme" is an international PhD training program carried out jointly by the four Vienna Biocenter research institutes (IMP, IMBA, GMI and MFPL). Acceptance into the program is competitive and based on a formal selection procedure. There are two selections each year, deadlines are April 30 and November 15. Participation in the program is a condition for doing a PhD at the IMP.<ref name="VBCPhDProgramme">{{cite web | title=Home | website=Vienna Biocenter PhD Programme | url=http://www.vbcphdprogramme.at/ | access-date=2018-02-18}}</ref>
==Building== [[File:IMP-outside.jpg|thumb|Research Institute of Molecular Pathology (IMP), outside view.]] The current IMP building at Campus-Vienna-Biocenter 1 was opened in 2017. It comprises 15,000 square meters of gross floor space and 8,000 square meters of net area, spread over eight levels.
The building contains 3,000 square meters for laboratories and 2,000 square meters for offices; its lecture hall seats up to 280 people. The buildings has six seminar rooms and technical facilities. Some facilities such as cafeteria, but also scientific services, are open to staff from other Vienna Biocenter entities and the IMP building is connected to the neighboring Institute of Molecular Biotechnology building through a bridge.
[[File:Spit-levels.jpg|thumb|Split-level architecture blending different floors and functions of the new IMP building.]]
Several features of the building refer to biological research: the facade features stripes should resemble [[DNA]] bands as seen in [[gel electrophoresis]]; the central elevator's glass covers are coated with [[Dichroic filter|dichroic foils]] which are also used in filters for light microscopy. The project costs of 52 million Euros were born by the IMP's main sponsor Boehringer Ingelheim.<ref name="LISAvienna 2017">{{cite web | title=IMP: New IMP Building: International Research Center Opens in Vienna | website=LISAvienna | date=2017-03-01 | url=http://lisavienna.at/en/news/imp-new-imp-building-international-research-center-opens-vienna | access-date=2018-02-18}}</ref>
==Scientific Advisory Board== In order to maintain a high standard of research, the IMP employs a process of continuous review and feedback. The Scientific Advisory Board (SAB), consisting of distinguished scientists, meets once a year and discusses the quality, significance, and main focus of research conducted at the IMP. The SAB is chaired by [[Leslie Vosshall]] of [[Rockefeller University]]. Its other members are [[Angelika Amon]] ([[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]); [[Hans Clevers]] ([[Hubrecht Institute]]); [[Michael Hausser]] ([[University College London]]); Norbert Kraut (Boehringer Ingelheim); [[Dan Littman]] ([[New York University]] Langone Medical Center); [[Ruslan Medzhitov]] ([[Yale School of Medicine]]/[[Howard Hughes Medical Institute|HHMI]]); [[Tom Rapoport]] ([[Harvard Medical School]]); [[Dirk Schübeler]] ([[Friedrich Miescher Institute]]).<ref name="IMPBoard">{{cite web | title=Scientific Advisory Board | website=The Research Institute of Molecular Pathology | url=https://www.imp.ac.at/about/advisory-board/ | access-date=2018-02-18}}</ref>
==Funding== The operating budget of the IMP is provided largely by Boehringer Ingelheim. Support comes from grants awarded to individual scientists and projects by national and international funding agencies such as the [[Austrian Science Fund]] (FWF), Austrian Industrial Research Promotion Fund (FFG), the Vienna Science and Technology Fund (WWTF), Zentrum für Innovation und Technologie (ZIT), the City of Vienna, the Austrian federal government, the Human Frontier Science Program (HFSP), and the European Union (EU).
==Notable people== ===Group leaders=== *[[Tim Clausen]]: molecular mechanisms of protein quality control *[[Jan-Michael Peters]]: [[mitosis]] and chromosome biology *[[Alexander Stark]]: systems biology of regulatory motifs and networks – towards understanding [[gene expression]] from the DNA sequence *[[Elly Tanaka]]: molecular mechanisms of vertebrate [[Regeneration (biology)|regeneration]]
===Alumni=== * [[Angelika Amon]], master student/PhD student, 1989-1993 * [[Denise Barlow]], group leader, 1988-1996 * [[Hartmut Beug]], senior scientist 1988-2010 * [[Adrian Bird]], senior scientist 1987-1990 * [[Max Birnstiel]], managing director 1989-1996 * [[Barry Dickson]], group leader 1998-2002; managing director 2006-2012 * [[Thomas Jenuwein]], group leader/senior scientist 1993-2008 * [[Kim Nasmyth]], senior scientist/managing director 1989-2003 * [[Giulio Superti-Furga]], PhD student 1988-1990 * [[Frank Uhlmann]], postdoc 1997-2000 * [[Erwin Friedrich Wagner|Erwin Wagner]], senior scientist/deputy director 1988-2008 * [[Martin Zenke]], group leader 1988-1995
==References== {{Reflist|35em}}
==External links== {{Commonscat|Research Institute of Molecular Pathology (Vienna)}} *{{Official|http://www.imp.ac.at}}
{{Vienna Biocenter}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = Safe Schools Coalition Australia |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |logo = Safe_Schools_Coalition_Australia_logo.jpg |abbreviation = SSCA<ref name="review"/> |motto = Proud to create change in schools |formation = 21 October 2010 | founding_location = [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] |type = [[NGO]] |status = | extinction = {{end date and age|2017|12|01}} |purpose = The safety and wellbeing of the [[LGBTIQ]] school community |headquarters = [[Melbourne]] |location = |region_served = |membership = of SSCA, 52<ref name = "November 2017">{{cite web|url=http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au/safe-schools/ |title= Join Us. Is your school a member?|work=Safe Schools Coalition Australia|accessdate=4 November 2017}}</ref> |membership_year = 2017 |language = |leader_title = SSCA Program Director |leader_name = Craig Comrie<ref name = "SSC contact">{{cite web|url=http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au/contact-us |title=Contact Us |work=Safe Schools Coalition Australia}}</ref><ref name = "CraigComrie">{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/safe-schools-coalition-looks-to-new-leader-as-funds-run-dry/news-story/d60098b8cb45539052aabd12a3d50c57 |title=Safe Schools Coalition looks to new leader as funds run dry |author=Urban, Rebecca|date=25 October 2016|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=19 November 2016}}</ref> |main_organ = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = {{url|http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au}} |remarks = }}
The '''Safe Schools Coalition Australia''' ('''SSCA''') is a national network of organisations working with school communities to create safer and more inclusive environments for [[Homosexuality|homosexual]], intersex and gender diverse students, staff and families.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au/who-we-are |title=The Safe Schools Coalition Australia |accessdate=21 December 2017}}</ref>
Prior to November 2017, SSCA functioned as a group of organisations in Australia focused on [[LGBTIQ]] people in schools. Its mission is to create [[Gay-friendly|safe and inclusive]] schools for students, families and staff who are in these groups.<ref name="about">{{cite web |url=http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au/who-we-are |title=Who are we |last1=Safe Schools Coalition Australia |publisher=Safe Schools Coalition Australia |accessdate=15 February 2016}}</ref> The primary activity of the SSCA is the Safe Schools Program that was developed to give support to teachers and schools who had been seeking assistance in the creation of a more inclusive environment for LGBTIQ students and their families.<ref name="fafa">{{cite web |url=https://www.fya.org.au/2016/02/12/fast-facts-about-safe-schools-coalition-australia/ |title=Fast Facts About Safe Schools Coalition Australia |author=Maggie Hill |publisher=The Foundation for Young Australians |accessdate=12 September 2016 }}</ref> The program began in Victorian schools in 2010 and expanded nationwide in 2013. The Program was the first of its kind in Australia. Schools are encouraged to customise the implementation of resources which are provided.<ref name="review"/><ref name="fafa"/> The SSCA is managed by [[The Foundation for Young Australians]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/early-warning-over-roz-ward-attack/news-story/00c31eb3691619dcb6c8f6660e2c55c3 |title=Early warning over Roz Ward attack |author=Urban, Rebecca|date=29 August 2016|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=31 August 2016}}</ref> and funded by various state governments. In October 2016 the federal government said that it would not renew its funding for the program.<ref name = "SSC contact"/><ref name = "CraigComrie"/> In December 2016, the [[Department of Education and Training (Victoria)|Education Department]] took control of the program in Victoria.<ref name= "SSCV"/><ref name= "DESPOGI"/><ref name = "SSCV2">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/no-backing-down-on-safe-schools-education-minister-james-merlino-tells-parents-20170211-guar7z.html |title=No backing down on Safe Schools, Education Minister James Merlino tells parents |author=Tomazin, Farrah|date=11 February 2017|work=[[The Age]]|accessdate=14 February 2017}}</ref>
The SSCA initially received bipartisan support from government. There is opposition to the program relating to [[sexuality]] and [[gender]] concepts being taught in schools.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/safe-schools-rainbow-ideology-fuels-sex-switches/news-story/54bf9f6eac7010b01818f0c5ea9cc28f |title=Safe Schools: ‘rainbow ideology’ fuels sex switches |author=Balogh, Stefanie |date=2 September 2016 |work=[[The Australian]] |accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref> In response an independent review was conducted in 2016. While some changes have been made since the review's findings were published, it recommended no major changes to the program and found that it was consistent with the [[Australian Curriculum|national curriculum]].<ref name=sbs/> The report recommended an increase in the availability of guidance on the use of included materials. Other changes recommended and subsequently implemented include making the program only available to high schools, removing role playing activities and the requirement for [[parental consent]] before participation.<ref name=sbs/>
In 2017 the SSCA program ceased in New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory pulled out (and with Tasmania to pull out) of the Safe Schools Coalition Australia program, with each developing their own programs. As of July 2017, 54 schools in WA, Tas and NT were nominated as SSCA members.<ref name ="July 2017">{{cite web|url=http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au/safe-schools/ |title=Join Us: Is your school a member |work=Safe Schools Coalition Australia|accessdate=5 July 2017}}</ref>
==Membership== The members of the Safe Schools Coalition Australia are The Foundation for Young Australians based in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Family Planning [[New South Wales|NSW]], the [[Western Australian]] AIDS Council, the Sexual Health and Family Planning [[Australian Capital Territory|ACT]], Shine SA - Sexual Health Information Networking & Education in [[South Australia]], True Relationships & Reproductive Health, [[Queensland]] and Working it out in [[Tasmania]].<ref name="about"/>
Schools are encouraged to join the coalition as members. The coalition began with 11 founding schools, including [[Methodist Ladies' College, Melbourne|Methodist Ladies' College]], [[Bellarine Secondary College]], [[MacRobertson Girls’ High School|MacRobertson Girls' High School]], Hallam Secondary and [[Princes Hill Secondary College]].<ref name="imad">{{Cite news |url=http://www.bordermail.com.au/story/3755992/safe-schools-program-is-making-a-difference/ |title=Safe Schools program is making a difference |author=Farrah Tomazin |accessdate=11 September 2016 |date=27 February 2016 |newspaper=The Border Mail |publisher=Fairfax Media }}</ref> [[St Joseph's College, Melbourne|St Joseph's College]] in Melbourne is a Catholic school taking part in the program.<ref name="pwa">{{Cite news |url=http://www.educatoronline.com.au/news/principal-warns-against-academic-impact-of-bullying-212561.aspx |title=Principal warns against academic impact of bullying |author=Brett Henebery |accessdate=12 September 2016 |date=4 March 2016 |work=The Educator |publisher=Key Media }}</ref><ref name="cpp"/>
In November 2016 the [[Salvation Army]] said it supports the program.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.salvationarmy.org.au/en/News-and-Media/news-and-media1/Salvation-Army-Supports-Safe-Schools-Initiative/ |title=Salvation Army Supports Safe Schools Initiative |author=Webb, Geoff|date=|work=[[Salvation Army]]|accessdate=19 November 2016}}</ref> Later in November that endorsement was withdrawn<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/salvation-army-in-retreat-on-safe-schools-program/news-story/12b1825e3d842abe5e960a58d304aa9e |title=Salvation Army in retreat on Safe Schools program |author=Urban, Rebecca|date=5 December 2016|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.starobserver.com.au/news/salvation-army-responds-backflip-safe-schools-support/154320 |title=Salvation Army backflips on Safe Schools support|author=Power, Shannon|date=5 December 2016|work=[[Star Observer]]|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> with the Salvation Army saying that it, "cannot unconditionally support the Safe Schools programs in Australia in their current form".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.salvationarmy.org.au/en/News-and-Media/news-and-media1/2016/The-Safe-Schools-Initiative/ |title=Salvation Army Announces National Position On Safe Schools |date=30 November 2016|work=[[Salvation Army]]|accessdate=1 December 2016}}</ref> In December 2016 [[Bega Valley Shire Council]] voted to support the program.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.begadistrictnews.com.au/story/4358187/safe-schools-program-gets-bega-valley-council-support/ |title=Safe Schools Program gets Bega Valley council support |author=Dion, Denise|date=15 December 2016|work=Bega District News|accessdate=18 January 2017}}</ref> However, in January 2017 the council rescinded that support.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.begadistrictnews.com.au/story/4411824/safe-schools-back-flip-by-bega-council/ |title=Safe School support rescinded in heated Bega council meeting|author=McKnight, Albert|date=18 January 2017|work=Bega District News|accessdate=18 January 2017}}</ref>
==Research== In describing the aims of the program, the Safe Schools Coalition Australia reports that "75% of same sex attracted young people experience some form of homophobic abuse or bullying... A staggering 80% of young people experienced abuse and bullying while at school",<ref name="allofus" /> more than anywhere else.<ref name="wti2010"/> The ''All Of Us'' resource<ref name="allofus" /> cites research on same sex attracted and gender diverse youth documented in the report, ''Writing Themselves in 3'', prepared by the [[La Trobe University]]'s, ''Australian Research Centre in Sex, Health and Society''.<ref name="wti2010">{{Cite book| isbn = 978-1-921377-92-1| last1 = Hillier| first1 = Lynne| last2 = Jones| first2 = Tiffany| last3 = Monagle| first3 = Marisa| last4 = Overton| first4 = Naomi| last5 = Gahan| first5 = Luke| last6 = Blackman| first6 = Jennifer| last7 = Mitchell| first7 = Anne| title = Writing Themselves in 3: The third national study on the sexual health and wellbeing of same sex attracted and gender questioning young people| location = Melbourne| date = 2010| publisher = Australian Research Centre in Sex, Health and Society, [[La Trobe University]] |url = http://glhv.org.au/files/wti3_web_sml.pdf}}</ref> Research on [[Intersex rights in Australia|intersex]] Australians published in 2016 shows that, while 2% of Australians fail to complete secondary school, 18% of Australians born with intersex variations fail to do so due to issues around bullying, discrimination and pubertal medical interventions.<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1080/14681811.2016.1149808| issn = 1468-1811| pages = 1–17| last = Jones| first = Tiffany| title = The needs of students with intersex variations| journal = Sex Education| accessdate = 2016-03-18| date = March 11, 2016| url = http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/14681811.2016.1149808}}</ref><ref name="carpenter">{{Cite web| last = Carpenter| first = Morgan| author-link1 = Morgan Carpenter | title = We support the Safe Schools Coalition Australia| accessdate = 15 February 2016| date = 11 February 2016 | url = https://oii.org.au/30360/support-ssca/ | publisher = [[Organisation Intersex International Australia]]}}</ref>
Research on student performance comparing those within to those without the program indicated gender diverse and same-sex-attracted young people did better with Safe Schools.<ref name="prre"/>
==Safe Schools Program== {| class="wikitable" style="float: right;" border="1" |- ! Date !! Member schools |- | October 2010 || 11 |- | July 2015 || 360<ref name="crs"/> |- | February 2016 || 490 |- | September 2016 || 545 |- | January 2017 || 304<ref name ="2017membership">{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/secrecy-over-safe-schools-in-nsw-criticised/news-story/7d58eeb7672fd26cdb97a2edf269b9bc |title=Secrecy over Safe Schools in NSW criticised |author=Urban, Rebecca|date=14 February 2017|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=14 February 2017}}</ref> |- | November 2017 || 52<ref name ="November 2017"/> |} The first community-based LGBTIQ youth groups in the fields of [[social services]] were established in the United States in the late 1970s. In the 1980s and 1990s a [[Abstinence-only sex education|sexual risk]] discourse dominated LGBTIQ issues in education policy in Victoria.<ref name="poan">{{cite book |title=Policy and Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual, Transgender and Intersex Students Volume 6 of Policy Implications of Research in Education |last=Jones |first=Tiffany |year=2013 |publisher=Springer |isbn=3319119915 |page=84 |url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=00EBBQAAQBAJ |accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref> Addressing school bullying with practical steps is a worldwide trend. The Safe Schools Coalition Australia provides resources such as this program as part of The National Safe Schools Framework which deals with the wider causes of [[bullying]].<ref name="frame">{{cite web |url=https://www.education.gov.au/national-safe-schools-framework-0 |title=The National Safe Schools Framework |publisher=Department of Education and Training |accessdate=13 September 2016 }}</ref>
This voluntary program, developed by the Safe Schools Coalition, commenced in Victoria on 21 October 2010,<ref name="cogf">{{Cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/education/coming-out-gay-friendly-schools-form-rainbow-alliance-20101020-16u7r.html |title=Coming out: gay friendly schools form Rainbow Alliance |author=Farrah Tomazin |accessdate=19 September 2016 |date=21 October 2010 |newspaper=The Age |publisher=Fairfax Media }}</ref> and received national funding of $8 million in 2013.<ref name="bita2">{{Cite web| last = Bita| first = Natasha| title = Sexual politics in the classroom| accessdate = 13 February 2016| date = 12 February 2016 |url=http://at.theaustralian.com.au/link/bf58ff141ba0b08bf165e3d53cc8a055?domain=theaustralian.com.au|publisher = [[The Australian]]}}</ref> Federal funding for the program was sought by openly gay Senator [[Penny Wong]], the ([[Australian Labor Party|ALP]]) Finance Minister in 2013. It was formally launched in June 2014 by the ([[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal]]) [[Abbott Government]].<ref>{{Citation| url = https://www.education.gov.au/news/safe-schools-coalition-australia-launched | title = Safe Schools Coalition Australia launched | publisher = [[Department of Education and Training (Australia)]] | date = 13 June 2014 |accessdate = 15 February 2016 }}</ref> The program is focused on "challenging the bullying and discrimination of the LGBTIQ community within the school setting".<ref name="cook">{{Cite news| last = Cook| first = Henrietta| title = Safe Schools program ordered to stay silent on gay marriage| work = The Age| accessdate = 15 February 2016| date = 28 July 2015| url = http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/safe-schools-program-ordered-to-stay-silent-on-gay-marriage-20150728-gimdrr.html}}</ref>
The program expanded nationally because of its success.<ref name="prre">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/feb/24/safe-schools-lgbti-program-researchers-receiving-abusive-emails-after-christian-lobby-campaign |title=Safe Schools LGBTI program researchers 'receiving abusive emails' after Christian lobby campaign |author=Melissa Davey |accessdate=11 September 2016 |date=12 February 2016 |work=theguardian }}</ref> Content was created by a number of experts in the field. [[Melbourne High School]] teacher Christopher Bush helped produce and write content.<ref name="idon">{{Cite news |url=http://gaynewsnetwork.com.au/feature/i-don-t-want-another-kid-killing-themselves-because-they-think-they-are-different-or-wrong-20529.html |title=‘I don’t want another kid killing themselves because they think they are different or wrong’ |author=Jacqui Tomlins |accessdate=12 September 2016 |date=1 March 2016 |work=Gay News Network }}</ref> The program runs in every state of Australia and the Australian Capital Territory,<ref name="about" /> and is planned to commence in the Northern Territory. As of mid February 2016, 490 schools were members of the program, and 86 organisations were supporters of the coalition.<ref name="about" /> According to the official website as of September 2016, 545 schools are members, up from the February 2016 figure when a campaign against the program commenced.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} In NSW there were originally 120 schools registered, however the education department determined that 89 of those schools had never accessed resources and had no intention to do so in the immediate future.<ref name = "parent view">{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/mp-demands-schools-offer-getout-option-on-gender-bully-scheme/news-story/15d65f8a5becb6b004aacc00230215c6 |title=MP demands schools offer get-out option on gender bully scheme |author=Balogh, Stephanie|date=15 September 2016|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=15 September 2016}}</ref>
The Safe Schools Program contains a range of materials from which principals and teachers may choose to include, allowing educators to decide what is appropriate for their schools.<ref name="oosh">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/feb/25/only-one-school-has-quit-safe-schools-lgbti-program-after-parents-objections |title=Only one school has quit Safe Schools LGBTI program after parents' objections |author=Shalailah Medhora |accessdate=11 September 2016 |date=25 February 2016 |work=theguardian }}</ref> Some schools present no classroom material to students.<ref name="sspiwa">{{Cite news |url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/wa/a/31197488/safe-schools-program-in-wa-grows/#page1 |title=Safe schools program in WA grows |author=Phoebe Wearne |accessdate=12 September 2016 |date=28 March 2016 |work=The West Australian }}</ref> There are four official guides, three official posters and eight lesson plans. Videos are available to accompany the lessons. In 2015, a teaching manual called ''All Of Us''<ref name = "allofus">{{cite web|url=http://www.education.vic.gov.au/Documents/about/programs/health/AllOfUs_UnitGuide.pdf |title=‌All Of Us| date = 2015| publisher = [[Department of Education and Training (Victoria)]]|accessdate=20 August 2016}}</ref> was launched, following approval by the federal Education Department.<ref name="bita2" /> Authors of the manual include Margot Fink, a finalist for [[Young Australian of the Year]] in 2016. The guide includes information on teaching gender diversity, [[sexual diversity]] and intersex topics. Resource content includes a video of same sex attracted and gender diverse youth, as well as intersex film-maker [[Phoebe Hart]].<ref name="allofus"/> A children's story book, entitled [[The Gender Fairy]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au/is-the-gender-fairy-in-your-school-library-5|title=Is ‘The Gender Fairy’ in your school library?|date=27 January 2016|work=Safe Schools Coalition|accessdate=16 September 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160329114810/http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au/is-the-gender-fairy-in-your-school-library-5|archivedate=29 March 2016|df=}}</ref> released in January 2016 and promoted by the Safe Schools Coalition,<ref name="bita2" /> explains transgender issues for young children. Safe Schools Coalition co-founder, Roz Ward<ref>{{cite news|url=http://gaynewsnetwork.com.au/feature/queers-of-melbourne-this-month-we-meet-roz-ward-from-safe-schools-22346.html |title=Queers of Melbourne This month we meet Roz Ward from Safe Schools|date=3 November 2016|work=Gay News Network|accessdate=19 November 2016}}</ref> has compiled the accompanying notes for teachers and parents.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/the-gender-fairy-a-new-chapter-in-transgender-education-for-kids-20151130-glbst8.html |title='The Gender Fairy': a new chapter in transgender education for kids |author=Perkins, Miki|date=2 December 2015|work=[[The Age]]|accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref> Safe Schools material provides advice for secondary students faced with [[Content-control software|explicit-content-filters]] on computers<ref name ="Stand Out page 12 & 18">{{cite web|url=http://www.safeschoolshub.edu.au/common/downloads/Stand-Out_2014.pdf |title=Stand out against homophobia and transphobia in schools |work=Safe Schools Coalition|first1=Roz |last1=Ward |first2=Scott |last2=Micah|page = 12 & 18 |accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> and with resistance to displaying LGBTIQ posters.<ref name ="Stand Out page 12 & 18"/> Child psychologist Michael Carr-Gregg says, "The civil disobedience is not wise."<ref name="bita2" />
The material challenges notions of [[heteronormativity]] and promotes acceptance of LGBTIQ people.<ref name="cpp"/> The goal is to achieve an understanding and tolerance of LGBTIQ individuals through education. Students are given the opportunity to challenge [[LGBT stereotypes]].<ref name="lmaos"/> Another aim is to reduce the incidence of [[Depression (mood)|depression]], [[suicide prevention|suicide]] and [[self-harm]].{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} Representatives from Safe Schools are available to meet with parents, students and teachers upon request.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
Some school principals reported a decrease in same-sex attracted and gender diverse students being [[School bullying|bullied]].<ref name="secg">{{Cite news |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/leader/south-east/schools-embrace-controversial-gender-program-that-the-lgbt-community-says-saves-lives/news-story/4f64da8a6bc0a90d1727910842e4dcc2?nk=8a29ffc6a7c0a4fccb3181c8924221c2-1473577472 |title=Schools embrace controversial gender program that the LGBT community says ‘saves lives’ |author=Lisa Schefman |accessdate=11 September 2016 |date=8 February 2016 |newspaper=Herald Sun |publisher=News Corp. }}</ref> Testimony from students has explained how the program improves the learning environment.<ref name="imad"/> There are reports that the introduction of the program has reduced the prevalence of homophobic and transphobic language at schools.<ref name="lmaos">{{cite web |url=https://aeunt.org.au/news/make-all-our-schools-safe-schools/ |title=Let’s make all our schools Safe Schools |date=26 May 2016 |publisher=Australian Education Union Northern Territory |accessdate=12 September 2016 }}</ref> In some instances the mere knowledge that a school is part of the coalition has increased the level of safety felt by LGBTIQ students.<ref name="imad"/>
Some parents of students who took part in the program have expressed dislike for changes to school policy in regards to bathroom use.<ref name="secg"/> Others have expressed concern that they did not know that this "[[ideology]]" was being "imposed" on their children.<ref name= "ScottReview"/> The Safe Schools Coalition actively encourages people to report any inappropriate content.<ref name="reinco">{{cite web |url=http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au/contact-us/report |title=Report Inappropriate Content |work=The Foundation for Young Australians |accessdate=12 September 2016 }}</ref>
==Reception== The program has been supported by the majority of state governments, as well as psychologists, gay-support groups and other non-governmental and religious organisations.<ref name="cogf"/><ref name="qgs">{{Cite news |url=http://www.starobserver.com.au/news/national-news/queensland-government-stands-by-safe-schools-coalition-australia/139201 |title=Queensland Government stands by Safe Schools Coalition Australia |author=David Alexander |accessdate=12 September 2016 |date=30 July 2016 |newspaper=Star Observer }}</ref> The program is supported by [[beyondblue]], [[headspace (organisation)|headspace]] and the Australian Secondary Principals Association.<ref name="chbi">{{Cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-02-26/safe-schools-chest-binding-photo-removed-from-christian-website/7202772 |title=Safe Schools: Chest binding photo removed from Christian website after complaints by young transgender man shown |author=Simon Leo Brown |accessdate=19 September 2016 |date=26 February 2016 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation }}</ref>
Advocates for the program point to high levels of homophobic abuse, including in school settings, and high levels of school leaving.<ref name="shaw">{{Cite news| last = Shaw| first = Rebecca| title = There is no such thing as a 'gay manual', but I wish I'd had this when I was a child| work = [[The Guardian]]| accessdate = 11 February 2016| date = 11 February 2016| url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/feb/11/there-is-no-such-thing-as-a-gay-manual-but-i-wish-id-had-this-when-i-was-a-child}}</ref> Australian LGBTIQ rights activist and academic [[Rodney Croome]] welcomed a review as a way of ensuring its funding delivered the outcomes it sought.<ref name="whha">{{Cite news |url=https://www.thesaturdaypaper.com.au/news/politics/2016/03/26/what-happened-the-safe-schools-program/14589108003049 |title=What happened to the Safe Schools program |author=Karen Middleton |accessdate=12 September 2016 |date=26 March 2016 |work=The Saturday Paper }}</ref> NSW Labor politician [[Penny Sharpe]] has said that opposition is primarily due to "[[homophobia]]" and "[[transphobia]]".<ref name="partridge"/> A petition presented by [[Australian Greens]] Senator [[Robert Simms (politician)|Robert Simms]] to Parliament in March 2016 contained 70,000 signatures in support of the organisation.<ref name="70,000">{{Cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com.au/2016/03/03/70-000-signatures-collected-in-support-of-safe-schools-coalition/ |title=70,000 Signatures Collected In Support Of Safe Schools Coalition |author=Josh Butler |accessdate=12 September 2016 |date=4 March 2016 |work=The Huffington Post Australia }}</ref>
However, the program is opposed by some religious groups, particularly the [[Christian right]], with the program said to be "gagged" on [[same-sex marriage]] while the Safe Schools Coalition said there had been "no change to media protocols".<ref name="cook" /> The [[Australian Christian Lobby]] and the Former National Party senator [[Bill O'Chee]] have criticised the program.<ref name="crs">{{Cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/parenting/school-life/christian-lobby-groups-claim-radical-sexual-experimentation-is-being-promoted-in-schools/news-story/39c64a960b2d112875848c4f337de433 |title=Christian lobby groups claim ‘radical sexual experimentation’ is being promoted in schools |author= |accessdate=12 September 2016 |date=25 July 2015 |work=news.com.au |publisher=News Limited }}</ref> Former Labor senator [[Joe Bullock]] has also criticised Safe Schools.<ref name="ssil">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/feb/25/safe-schools-is-like-child-grooming-says-nationals-mp-george-christensen |title=Safe Schools is like child grooming, says Nationals MP George Christensen |author=Australian Associated Press |accessdate=12 September 2016 |date=25 February 2016 |work=The Guardian }}</ref> Former Democrats Senator [[Brian Greig]] stated that the criticism from religious conservatives echoed the 1997 conservative response to "Here for Life", the anti-suicide program introduced by the [[Keating Government]]'s [[Carmen Lawrence]] for gay and lesbian teenagers.<ref name="grieg">{{cite news|last1=Grieg|first1=Brian|title=History repeats: 20 years of political homophobia from the religious right|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/mar/30/history-repeats-20-years-of-political-homophobia-from-the-religious-right|accessdate=21 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=30 March 2016}}</ref> After conservatives described it as “promoting homosexuality” and “recruiting children”, the newly elected [[Howard Government]] cancelled the Here for Life program.<ref name="grieg" />
Various aspects of the program have been criticised by ''[[The Australian]]'' newspaper.<ref name="bita2" /><ref name="Shan">{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/opinion/columnists/angela-shanahan/parents-are-the-best-judge-of-their-kids-sex-education-needs/news-story/a4735e9b23790a3769ac99d97d656253 |title=Parents are the best judge of their kids’ sex education needs |author=Shanahan, Angela|date=27 February 2016|work=The Australian|accessdate=26 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/safe-schools-activist-roz-ward-raises-red-flag/news-story/42208731b0e4705aa0d2e6aaa8584e3e |title=Safe Schools activist Roz Ward raises ‘red flag’ |author=Urban, Rebecca|date=1 March 2016|work=The Australian|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/safe-schools-tell-concerned-parents-tough-luck/news-story/cc2e9d420e9cddf5ddf1d94849d0d9f4 |title=Safe Schools: tell concerned parents ‘tough luck!’ |author=Urban, Rebecca|date=22 March 2016|work=The Australian|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/kids-of-7-learn-gender-diversity-from-safe-schools-coalition/news-story/b06172309839e02b2a0dffe36a14556f |title=Kids of 7 learn ‘gender diversity’ from Safe Schools Coalition |author=Urban, Rebecca|date=14 May 2016|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=15 May 2016}}</ref> In July 2015, the [[Australian Christian Lobby]] lodged a 10,891-signature petition with the [[Parliament of Queensland|Queensland parliament]] in relation to the Safe Schools program.<ref name="partridge">{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/australian-christian-lobby-slams-safe-schools-antibullying-program-20151103-gkq6gr.html |title=Australian Christian Lobby slams Safe Schools anti-bullying program | author=Partridge, Emma|date=4 November 2015|work=Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=26 March 2016}}</ref> The petition incorporated wording from a Safe Schools student resource. However the Clerk of the Parliament would not permit that wording on the Queensland parliament’s website because of the "intemperate" language.<ref name="Shan"/> The petition was subsequently tabled with that offending wording removed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.parliament.qld.gov.au/apps/Epetitions/ClosedEpetition.aspx?PetNum=2429 |title= Cease Safe Schools roll out in Queensland schools |date= 13 October 2015|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref>
On 14 February 2016 the education minister, [[Simon Birmingham]], described the lessons prepared by the coalition as having "reasonable objectives". Birmingham stated that controversy over the program was "very unhelpful because the debate that seems to be occurring in the public space is one of whether or not we should be teaching inclusiveness and tolerance in our schools".<ref name="owens">{{Cite web| last = Owens| first = Jared| title = Sex diversity class ‘reasonable’| accessdate = 14 February 2016| date = 14 February 2016| url = http://at.theaustralian.com.au/link/17a555b13b0eddc57bdb2a385606dec6?domain=theaustralian.com.au| publisher = [[The Australian]]}}</ref> Some of the [[Anti-LGBT rhetoric|negative]] commentary surrounding the program has been attributed to the belief that young people who are exposed to LGBTIQ issues might then change their sexuality.<ref name="cpp">{{Cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/catholic-principal-pressured-to-withdraw-from-safe-schools-coaltion-20160301-gn7h6h.html |title=Catholic principal pressured to withdraw from Safe Schools Coalition |author=Henrietta Cook |accessdate=12 September 2016 |date=1 March 2016 |newspaper=The Age |publisher=Fairfax Media }}</ref> The current (as of November 2017) federal government's policy is not to fund the program beyond 2017.<ref name="wbf17">{{Cite news |url=http://www.starobserver.com.au/news/national-news/federal-government-to-make-changes-to-safe-schools-program-following-review/147634 |title=Safe Schools won’t be funded beyond 2017 |author=Shannon Power |accessdate=12 September 2016 |date=28 March 2016 |newspaper=Star Observer }}</ref> Resources will still be available for schools to use beyond that date. Labor's policy is to expand the Safe Schools Coalition.<ref name="imad"/>
{{ external media | float = | width = 25% | image1 = [http://www.safeschoolshub.edu.au/common/downloads/Change-is-Coming-poster_2014.pdf Change is coming poster] | image2 = [http://www.safeschoolshub.edu.au/common/downloads/All-Of-Us-Classroom-Poster.pdf Classroom poster] | image3 = | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gCjKyKO6zT0 Cory Bernardi Speech to the Senate] | video2 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xH0V-AnnnRw George Christensen Speech to the House of Representatives] | video3 = }}
In February 2016, under privilege of Parliament, [[George Christensen (politician)|George Christensen]] claimed the program exposed students to inappropriate sexual material.<ref name="gmpgc">{{Cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com.au/2016/02/25/christensen-grooming_n_9322362.html |title=Government MP George Christensen Likens LGBT 'Safe Schools' Program To 'Paedophile Grooming' |author=Josh Butler |accessdate=12 September 2016 |date=26 February 2016 |work=The Huffington Post Australia }}</ref> Christensen also likened the program to a "[[pedophile]] grooming a victim",<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-02-23/turnbull-requests-investigation-into-safe-schools-program/7192374 | title = PM wants probe into LGBTI program over 'indoctrination' fears | website = ABC News | language = en-AU | access-date = 29 February 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/gay-senator-asks-liberal-colleagues-to-have-empathy-for-young-people-in-safe-schools-debate-20160226-gn4kmw.html | title = Gay senator asks Liberal colleagues to have empathy for young people in Safe Schools debate | website = The Sydney Morning Herald | accessdate = 29 February 2016 }}</ref> said the program was attempting to introduce into schools "queer [[gender theory]]" and "[[marxist ideology]]" that should be limited to universities.<ref name="concerns">{{cite news|url= http://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/abbott-told-of-safe-schools-concerns-mps/news-story/380d5a6884c4e6e5ac61eb93d9d5db6c | title=Abbott told of Safe Schools concerns: MPs |date=17 March 2016|work=[[News Ltd]] }}</ref> The Safe Schools Coalition dismissed those claims in their entirety.<ref name="cwc">{{Cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/pm-should-reprimand-homophobic-mp/news-story/1438636056250f22af30c6e73067bdf4 |title=Choose words carefully on Safe Schools: PM |author=Rashida Yosufzai |accessdate=19 September 2016 |date=26 February 2016 |work=news.com.au |publisher=News Limited }}</ref>
==Louden Review== A review was announced by the [[Turnbull Government|Turnbull Liberal/National Coalition Government]] on 26 February 2016, after Coalition backbenchers [[George Christensen (politician)|George Christensen]] and [[Cory Bernardi]] raised concerns over what they claimed was the "[[sexualised]]" nature of the program, and forty-three Coalition backbenchers including former leader [[Tony Abbott]] had signed a petition calling for the program's closure.<ref name="review"/><ref name=sbs/><ref>[http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/safe-schools-malcolm-turnbull-forced-to-act-on-funding-for-controversial-sexed-program/news-story/51dfbc4b15e86483632f6f6909bdac15 Safe Schools - Malcolm Turnbull forced to act on funding for controversial sex-ed program: Daily Telegraph 18 March 2016]</ref><ref>[http://indaily.com.au/news/2016/03/18/limits-imposed-on-safe-schools-program/ Limits imposed on Safe Schools program: InDaily 18 March 2016]</ref> The review did not consider the contents of the Minus 18<ref name = "Minus18"/> website, or the contents of the network partners’ websites. The review was conducted by [[University of Western Australia]]’s Professor Bill Louden.<ref name="wbf17"/> The process included interviews with a range of individuals and groups associated with the program.<ref name="wbf17"/>
On 11 March 2016 the ''Review of Appropriateness and Efficacy of the Safe Schools Coalition Australia Program Resources'' was published.<ref name="review">{{Cite web|url=https://docs.education.gov.au/system/files/doc/other/review_of_appropriateness_and_efficacy_of_the_ssca_program_resources_0.pdf|title=Review of Appropriateness and Efficacy of the Safe Schools Coalition Australia Program Resources|last=Louden|first=William|date=11 March 2016|website=Australian Government Department of Education and Training|publisher=Department of Education and Training Australia|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref>
===Findings=== The review revealed that opponents to the program had made statements that grossly misrepresented and exaggerated the nature of the program. Coalition MPs who support Safe School such as [[Warren Entsch]] said the concerns were being pushed by external lobby groups. Labor leader [[Bill Shorten]] labelled the Christensen group "[[ideologues]] ... trying to impose a 1950s view of the world".<ref name=sbs>[http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2016/03/18/limits-imposed-safe-schools-program Safe Schools program downsized after campaign by right-wing MPs and Christian lobby groups: SBS 18 March 2016]</ref><ref name="concerns"/><ref>[http://www.9news.com.au/national/2016/03/17/03/33/most-mps-back-safe-schools-cut-christensen Abbott told of Safe Schools concerns: Nine News 17 March 2016]</ref>
{{Quote box |title = | border=2px |quote = "The review does not consider the contents of the Minus 18 website, or the contents of the network partners’ websites, ... <br />...<br />All of the official resources are consistent with the intent and objectives of the program, in that they focus on one or both of the SSCA’s two overall aims, reducing homophobic and transphobic behaviour and intersex prejudice, and increasing support for same sex attracted, intersex and gender diverse students." |author = William Louden |source = ''Review of Appropriateness and Efficacy of the Safe Schools Coalition Australia Program Resources''<ref name="review"/> |width = 25% | bgcolor = Cornsilk }}
The review did not find that any of the official resources were inappropriate. It found that the content in guideline documents was consistent with the aims of the program and that the language and content was suitable.<ref name="review"/> All lesson plans were found to be consistent with the aims of the program as were all the posters. No harm was expected to come from primary schools students viewing the material, just that they may not comprehend some terms such as transphobia or homophobia.<ref name="review"/> The level of interaction between schools and parents was found to be appropriate.<ref name="review"/>
The Safe School Coalition has links to affiliate, third-party organisations<ref name="third-party">{{cite web |url=http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au/app/theme/default/design/assets/all-of-us/documents/student-handouts.pdf |title=All of us - student handouts |work=Safe Schools Coalition |page=8 |accessdate=29 March 2016 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160301215611/http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au/app/theme/default/design/assets/all-of-us/documents/student-handouts.pdf |archivedate=1 March 2016 |df= }}</ref> and have jointly produced resources.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au/all-of-us |title= All of us|work=Safe Schools Coalition|accessdate=29 March 2016}}</ref> Several of these resources, including ''Stand Out'',<ref name ="standout">{{cite web|url=http://www.safeschoolshub.edu.au/common/downloads/Stand-Out_2014.pdf |title=Stand out |last1 = Minus18 |last2 = Safe Schools Coalition|date=September 2014|accessdate=20 August 2016}}</ref> created in 2011 by the Safe Schools Coalition Victoria and Minus18<ref name = "Minus18">{{cite web|url=https://minus18.org.au/ |title=Minus18 |work=Minus18|accessdate=29 March 2016}}</ref> were part of the Louden Review.
