The review found that, "The three resources created by young people, ''OMG I’m Queer'',<ref name="queer">{{cite web|url=http://ourcolours.org.au/wp-content/uploads/OMG%20I'm%20Queer_July%202015.pdf |title=OMG I'm Queer|last1 = Minus18 |last2 = Safe Schools Coalition|date =July 2015 |accessdate=20 August 2016}}</ref> ''OMG My Friend’s Queer''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.education.vic.gov.au/Documents/about/programs/health/OMGMyFriendIsQueer.pdf |title=OMG My Friend’s Queer|last1 = Minus18 |last2 = Safe Schools Coalition |accessdate=20 August 2016}}</ref> and ''Stand Out'',<ref name ="standout"/> are not intended as classroom resources. They are not normally circulated to primary schools and in some states only circulated to secondary schools on request. They normally are available either in the school library or through the student support centre. They are suitable for use by individual secondary students but may not be suitable for use in some faith-based schools."<ref name="review"/>
==Criticisms== In May 2016, [[Queenslander of the Year]] and transgender woman [[Cate McGregor]], who "had been asked to be an Ambassador for the program and had initially agreed",<ref name=DailyTelegraph20160910>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/rendezview/i-am-transgender-and-i-oppose-safe-schools/news-story/7e194d1cc3037b6966b9fdab59871bf9|title=I am transgender. And I oppose Safe Schools|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|author=Catherine McGregor|date=18 May 2016|accessdate=10 September 2016}}</ref> subsequently said that she does not agree that the Safe Schools program is the best way to support transgender children. McGregor said she objects to the program as she believes it is underpinned by a [[political ideology]] with which she does not agree, saying that the program "teaches a derivative of [[queer theory]], which I believe leads trans people into a blind alley".<ref name=DailyTelegraph20160910/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.outinperth.com/catherine-mcgregor-speaks-safe-schools/ |title=Catherine McGregor speaks out against Safe Schools |date=19 May 2016|work=Out In Perth|accessdate=7 September 2016}}</ref> McGregor was subsequently stood down as the patron of [[Kaleidoscope Australia Human Rights Foundation|Kaleidoscope Australia]] for her opposition to the Safe Schools program. McGregor expressed her disappointment.<!--- Drovers' Wife said, "perhaps add a one-sentence quote from McGregor herself about the backlash against her for that stance". Feel free to reword this ----><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.samesame.com.au/news/14199/Catherine-McGregor-dropped-from-LGBT-group-over-anti-Safe-School-comments |title=Catherine McGregor dropped from LGBT group over anti-Safe School comments|author=|date=7 September 2016|work=[[Samesame.com.au|Same Same]]|accessdate=6 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.starobserver.com.au/news/catherine-mcgregors-angry-response-kaleidoscope-australia-sacking/152607 |title=Catherine McGregors angry response to Kaleidoscope Australia sacking |author=Power, Shannon|date=6 September 2016|work=[[Star Observer]]|accessdate=7 September 2016}}</ref>
However, in May 2018, McGregor declared she had been wrong about the program. "It's an excellent program, and it saves lives." "I should have been a supporter from the start. I regret that I wasn't." "Young trans people need an ally, and I could have been one." "I'm high profile. They looked up to me. I could have helped, and I didn't, and I regret that."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/kate-mcgregor-declares-herself-wrong-to-oppose-safe-schools/news-story/89acd91f3a5fff9bbd0ae44045403757 |title=Cate McGregor declares herself wrong to oppose Safe Schools |first=Caroline |last=Ovington |date=3 May 2018 |work=The Australian |accessdate=3 May 2018}}</ref>
In her column in Fairfax Media she said "to my chagrin, I failed to anticipate the ammunition I offered to those like Miranda Devine and Lyle Shelton who refuse outright to accept the reality and legitimacy of trans identity." "Trans kids are still doing it tough. Mainly because of cruel religious fanatics and their enablers."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.smh.com.au/education/encounter-made-me-realise-i-was-wrong-to-oppose-safe-schools-20180503-p4zd1s.html |title=Encounter made me realise I was wrong to oppose Safe Schools |first=Catherine |last=McGregor |work=Sydney Morning Herald |date=3 May 2018 |accessdate=3 May 2018}}</ref>
In June 2016, [[La Trobe University]] suspended Roz Ward, the British academic and activist who "runs the Safe Schools Coalition" through the university's Australian Research Centre in Sex, Health and Society, for saying she wanted to get rid of the "racist" [[Flag of Australia|Australian flag]] and replace it with a [[Red flag (politics)|red flag]], "and my work is done". Ward was also suspended from the Safe Schools program.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/roz-ward-suspended-from-controversial-safe-schools-program/news-story/0efe742b54db6abab5d8d91d2dc7c17b |title=Roz Ward suspended from controversial Safe Schools program |author=Cavanagh, Rebekah|date=2 June 2016|work=[[Herald Sun]]|accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref> The Prime Minister [[Malcolm Turnbull]] said Ward's actions "underlined concerns many people had about how the program was managed".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/breaking-news/safe-schools-manager-quits-over-gaffe/news-story/0239e50da2ad01234611986a78714d33 |title=Flag slur underlines concerns: Turnbull |date=28 May 2016|work=[[Herald Sun]]|accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref> Ward's solicitors wrote to the university's Vice-Chancellor, John Dewar, urging him to withdraw all allegations and reinstate her by 10am Monday, otherwise legal action would ensue. While Dewar defended the University's actions, he reinstated Ward, with the [[National Tertiary Education Union|Teachers Union]] saying Ward would be then able to resume supporting young people who are bullied.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/law-order/safe-schools-roz-ward-to-sue-la-trobe-university-unless-they-drop-misconduct-investigation/news-story/72c9bc255672d1eff66b274c5bf4623a |title=Safe Schools’ Roz Ward to sue La Trobe University unless they drop misconduct investigation |author=Cavanagh, Rebekah|date=3 June 2016|work=[[Herald Sun]]|accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref> Beyondblue provided almost $600,000 to La Trobe University to administer the Safe Schools program. However, its chairman, [[Jeff Kennett]], threatened to withdraw future funding and called for Ward to resign because of her "extreme political views".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/jeff-kennett-safe-schools-funding-lost-if-roz-ward-stays/news-story/0aef42a2d0c918d5dc7450683b581f33 |title=Jeff Kennett: Safe Schools funding lost if Roz Ward stays |author=Brown, Greg|date=31 May 2016|work=The Australian|accessdate=7 September 2016}}</ref>
In July 2016, members of Sydney's Chinese community lodged a petition containing more than 17,000 signatures, against the Safe Schools program.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-08-23/safe-schools-mp-lodges-petition-against-program-signed-by-17000/7777030 |title=Safe Schools: Australian Chinese community petition against anti-bullying program lodged in NSW |author=Kozaki, Danuta|date=24 August 2016|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|accessdate=31 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/aug/23/safe-school-program-thousands-nsw-sign-petition-against |title=Safe Schools program: thousands in NSW sign petition calling for it to be scrapped |date=23 August 2016|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=31 August 2016}}</ref> The chairman of the Confederation of Indian Australian Associations has said, "It should not be given that platform in the school lessons, the majority of Indians feel … school is not an appropriate place to bring this subject up."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/indians-join-chinese-concerned-about-safe-schools-rollout/news-story/c6b7263ba070ede2ea78416c957b5207 |title=Indians join Chinese concerned about Safe Schools rollout |author=Akerman, Pia|date=25 August 2016|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=31 August 2016}}</ref>
Dr Kevin Donnelly, who advocates for conservative viewpoints in discussions of education and established an institute which promotes the inclusion of Christian beliefs in schools<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cadzow|first1=Jane|title=Back to basics|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/back-to-basics-20140706-3bh7i.html|accessdate=1 January 2018|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=12 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=National curriculum review: Who is Kevin Donnelly?|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/national-curriculum-review-who-is-kevin-donnelly|accessdate=1 January 2018|work=SBS News|date=10 January 2014}}</ref> and was previously co-chair of the National Curriculum Review and Senior Research Fellow at the [[Australian Catholic University]], has argued that the program may over-ride parents' rights as primary caregivers and impose an agenda on their children which they might not accept.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/opinion/kevin-donnelly-how-ideology-took-over-schools/news-story/9f06e062476a2e04c7999b48d630b043 |title=Kevin Donnelly: How ideology took over schools |author=Donnelly, Kevin|date=21 July 2016|work=[[Herald Sun]]|accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref> Donnelly has also said there is a lack of transparency with the program in New South Wales.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.onlineopinion.com.au/view.asp?article=18731 |title=Education minister stubbornly oversees safe schools information blackout|author=Donnelly, Greg|date=16 December 2016|work=Online Opinion|accessdate=17 December 2016}}</ref>
The [[Australian Human Rights Commission]] expressed concern over attempts to impose parental consent requirements, stating that there needed to be careful consideration of its impact on children struggling with sexual orientation, gender identity or intersex status, and stating "while we recognise the rights of parents to be informed and engaged in their child’s education, it is important to ensure children who have not yet ‘come out’ to their family can still access the program and its resources.”<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.humanrights.gov.au/news/media-releases/commission-responds-independent-review-safe-schools-program | title=Commission responds to independent review of the Safe Schools program | publisher=Australian Human Rights Commission | date=18 March 2016 | accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref>
Former Prime Minister [[John Howard]] has said, "What’s disappointed me is an issue like Safe Schools. When that emerged it should have been hit on the head by centre-right governments at federal and state level".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/opinion/columnists/paul-kelly/the-crisis-for-conservatism/news-story/30a044c9b92c79a9428e7a65d89f24c1 |title=The crisis for conservatism |author=Kelly, Paul|date=25 February 2017|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=25 February 2017}}</ref>
In April 2017, Victorian education officials conceded there is a lack of hard evidence on the rates of homophobic bullying in schools to justify the decision to mandate the Safe School program.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/safe-schools-victorias-det-cant-prove-homophobic-bullying/news-story/11b9fe2832a44e3cd39041a6d94566a0 |title=Safe Schools: Victoria’s DET can’t prove homophobic bullying }}</ref>
On 9 May 2017 the [[Australian Christian Lobby]] hosted a seminar in Melbourne entitled ''Is Safe Schools safe?'', with the speakers, Professor of [[Paediatrics]] at the [[University of Western Sydney]], John Whitehall<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.westernsydney.edu.au/staff_profiles/uws_profiles/professor_john_whitehall |title=Professor John Whitehall |work=[[University of Western Sydney]]|date=12 May 2017 |accessdate=13 May 2017}}</ref> and Dr Elisabeth Taylor from ACL. About 30 people, several of whom had their faces covered with bandanas, blocked the entrance to the seminar stopping the majority of the attendees from entering.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/protesters-promise-to-shut-down-australian-christian-lobby-event-against-safe-schools-program/news-story/90e793eef753a02759d257ae9e28a779 |title=Protesters promise to shut down Australian Christian Lobby event against Safe Schools program |author=Hore, Monique |work=[[Herald Sun]]|date=9 May 2017 |accessdate=13 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/safe-schools-protest-targets-arrow-on-swanston-hotel/news-story/136e776a1f33c7275fc7613dcc3eb82c |title=Safe Schools protest targets Arrow on Swanston hotel |author=Akerman, Tessa|work=[[The Australian]]|date=9 May 2017 |accessdate=13 May 2017}}</ref> Safe Schools activists from the [[Community Action Against Homophobia]] group protested outside a similar event in Sydney.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/prosafe-schools-activists-protest-christian-lobby-event-in-sydney/news-story/805b22d86052d52f81e9ba19eda42b81 |title=Pro-Safe Schools activists protest Christian Lobby event in Sydney |author=Ritchie, Emily|date=28 July 2017|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=4 August 2017}}</ref>
In Canberra there were "acts of intimidation" made against those opposed to the Safe Schools Program. Anti safe schools signs were "torn up, burnt and defaced with threats to kill".<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/christian-democratic-partys-anti-safe-school-campaign-signs-defaced-20170614-gwqrdp.html |title=Christian Democratic Party's anti Safe School campaign signs defaced |author=Connery, Georgina|date=14 June 2017|work=[[The Canberra Times]]|accessdate=5 July 2017}}</ref>
In August 2017, a rally to protest against the Safe Schools program in Canberra was, "effectively drowned out by vocal supporters" of the program.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/canberra-antisafe-schools-rally-drowned-out-by-prolgbti-protesters-20170812-gxuwzo.html |title=Canberra Anti-Safe Schools rally drowned out by pro-LGBTI protesters |author=Williams, Elliot|date=13 August 2017|work=Canberra Times|accessdate=13 August 2017}}</ref>
===Australian Marriage Law Postal Survey=== Issues relating to the Safe Schools program were raised during the [[Australian Marriage Law Postal Survey]] debate.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2017/aug/29/coalition-for-marriage-ad-blitz-links-marriage-equality-to-gender-education |title=Coalition for Marriage ad blitz links marriage equality to gender education |author=Karp, Paul|date=29 August 2017|work=The Guardian|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref><ref name = "Bernardi">{{cite news|url=http://www.skynews.com.au/news/top-stories/2017/08/31/gay-marriage-advocates-hit-back-at--no--ads.html |title=Same-sex marriage 'a rainbow Trojan horse' |date=31 August 2017|work=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref> The head of the Australian Christian Lobby wrote in August 2017 that the survey would be a referendum on safe schools, and the [[Australian Conservatives]] political party wrongly claimed that "Safe Schools and others like it will be mandatory in schools" if same-sex marriage was legalised.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shelton|first1=Lyle|title=What The Marriage Plebiscite Is Really About|url=http://www.acl.org.au/what_the_marriage_plebiscite_is_really_about#splash-signup|publisher=Australian Christian Lobby|accessdate=1 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Louden|first1=Bill|title=FactCheck: will Safe Schools be ‘mandatory’ if same-sex marriage is legalised?|url=https://theconversation.com/factcheck-will-safe-schools-be-mandatory-if-same-sex-marriage-is-legalised-84437|website=The Conversation|accessdate=1 January 2018}}</ref> There is however a new program called [http://www.education.vic.gov.au/about/programs/Pages/respectfulrelationships.aspx Respectful Relationships]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.education.vic.gov.au/about/programs/Pages/respectfulrelationships.aspx|title=Respectful Relationships|website=www.education.vic.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref> which is different to Safe Schools, and was developed in response to recommendations made by the Australian Royal Commission on Family Violence. The Respectful Relationships program covers topics such as emotional literacy, anger management, coping skills, problem solving skills, anti-bullying, how to seek help from others, and gender equality.
In September 2017, the book ''[[The Gender Fairy]]'', promoted by the Safe Schools Coalition,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au/is-the-gender-fairy-in-your-school-library-5|title=Is 'The Gender Fairy' in your school library?|date=27 January 2016|work=Safe Schools Coalition|accessdate=16 September 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160329114810/http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au/is-the-gender-fairy-in-your-school-library-5|archivedate=29 March 2016|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| last = Bita| first = Natasha| title = Sexual politics in the classroom| accessdate = 17 September 2017| date = 12 February 2016 |url=http://at.theaustralian.com.au/link/bf58ff141ba0b08bf165e3d53cc8a055?domain=theaustralian.com.au|publisher = [[The Australian]]}}</ref> featured in a television ad released in conjunction with the [[Australian Marriage Law Postal Survey]] for the "No" campaign. The ad incorporates the words, "Only you know whether you are a boy or a girl".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2017/09/15/no-campaign-targets-gender-fairy-new-ad |title='No' campaign targets 'The Gender Fairy' in new ad |author=|date=16 September 2017|work=[[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]]|accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref>
==Federal position== Education Minister Simon Birmingham outlined the federal government's action in response to the Louden Review in a media statement.<ref name="birmedia">{{cite web |url=http://ministers.education.gov.au/birmingham/statement-safe-schools-coalition |title=Statement On Safe Schools Coalition |date=18 March 2016 |work=Media Release |publisher=Department of Education and Training |accessdate=12 September 2016 }}</ref> The Turnbull Liberal/National Coalition Government was quick to adopt changes to the program following the review. Some of the actions taken by the Turnbull Government were not recommended in the review.<ref name="sgao">{{Cite news |url=http://www.starobserver.com.au/news/national-news/state-governments-at-odds-over-safe-schools/147813 |title=State Governments at odds over Safe Schools |author=Alistair Kitchen |accessdate=12 September 2016 |date=23 March 2016 |newspaper=Star Observer }}</ref> The imposed limits included changes to some materials, limiting access to secondary schools as some material was not easily understood by younger students, and requiring parent opt-ins.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2016/03/18/limits-imposed-safe-schools-program | title = Safe Schools program downsized after campaign by right-wing MPs and Christian lobby groups | publisher = SBS News | date = 18 March 2016 | access-date = 18 March 2016 }}</ref> Federal President of the [[Australian Education Union]] Correna Haythorpe criticised the decision requiring parent body consent before a school could instigate the program saying that decision should be made by educators.<ref name="sscom">{{cite web |url=http://www.aeufederal.org.au/news-media/news/safe-schools-compromised |title=Safe Schools Compromised |date=21 March 2016 |work= |publisher=Australian Education Union |accessdate=13 September 2016 }}</ref>
The Federal Government ceased its funding of the Safe Schools program in October 2016.<ref name = "CraigComrie"/>
==State and Territory Government positions== The program operates extensively in Victoria and is fully funded by the state government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.education.vic.gov.au/about/programs/health/Pages/safe-schools-coalition.aspx?Redirect=1|title=Safe Schools|work=Victorian Government|date=1 November 2017}}</ref> State governments are also fully responsible for directly funded programs in South Australia<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.decd.sa.gov.au/supporting-students/health-e-safety-and-wellbeing/safe-schools|title=Safe Schools Anti-bullying Initiative|date=1 November 2017|work=South Australian Government}}</ref> and the Australian Capital Territory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shfpact.org.au/about-us/news-updates/284-sscact-2016|title=Safe Schools Coalition ACT|date=5 October 2016|work=Sexual Health and Family Planning (ACT Government)}}</ref> Several schools in Western Australia, Queensland, Tasmania and the Northern Territory remain signed up to national Safe Schools registry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.safeschoolscoalition.org.au/safe-schools/|title=Join Us - Is Your School A Member?|work=Safe Schools Coalition Australia|date=1 July 2017}}</ref>
===New South Wales=== Following the launch of a Safe Schools-based teaching resource, NSW Education Minister [[Adrian Piccoli]] ordered his department to immediately withdraw the material, stating "Safe Schools materials are only to be used strictly in accordance with the revised guidelines established by the federal government,"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/schools-told-to-teach-kids-that-sex-varies-like-the-weather/news-story/ccbd63c1a2a97ad073808425efbe8387 |title=Schools told to teach kids that sex varies like the weather |author=Urban, Rebecca|date=7 September 2016|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=7 September 2016}}</ref> with the Minister tasking [[Mark Scott (businessman)|Mark Scott]], the Secretary of the [[Department of Education (New South Wales)|NSW Education Department]], to undertake a review of the program.<ref name="ScottReview">{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/new-education-boss-told-to-review-controversial-sexed-course/news-story/9355918a93cd331318e94a75da08c423 |title=New education boss told to review controversial sex-ed course |author=Urban, Rebecca|date=12 December 2016|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref> In its report, released in November, the committee "recommends the NSW Education Department requires schools under the Controversial Issues in Schools policy to consult with parents prior to any implementation of the Safe Schools program, and require that parents choose whether to opt in to this program".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/safe-schools-should-have-opt-in-choice-recommends-committee/news-story/1931ba95d07afd897290c1a2a11a7032 |title=Safe Schools should have opt in choice recommends committee |author=Balogh, Stefanie|date=18 November 2016|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=19 November 2016}}</ref>
In September 2016, NSW students were told not to participate in any class lessons involving Safe Schools Coalition materials without the consent of their parents.<ref name = "parent view"/>
In February 2017, it was announced that NSW public school teachers were provided with, "a list of resources that should not be used."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/gender-theory-banned-in-nsw-classrooms/news-story/eeb40f3264394798ebe67260fa2f5782 |title=Gender theory banned in NSW classrooms |author=Urban, Rebecca |date=6 February 2017|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=25 February 2017}}</ref>
In April 2017 it was announced that NSW government will replace the Safe Schools Program with a broader anti-bullying program.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/safe-schools-program-to-be-dumped-by-nsw-government/news-story/74908c1a4cd7a8c355f44043f06740a9 |title=Safe Schools program to be dumped by NSW Government |author=Devine, Miranda|date=16 April 2017|work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=16 April 2017}}</ref>
In August 2017 it was reported that, "education bureaucrats have tried to slip material from the program back into the classroom, in defiance of parental wishes and ministerial orders",<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/opinion/editorial-safe-schools-returns-almost/news-story/b13e325585ecb98fcf3a7fd911037557 |title=Editorial: Safe Schools returns — almost |date=17 August 2017|work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> with the federal [[Minister for Immigration and Border Protection]], [[Peter Dutton]] saying those responsible should be "sacked".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/safe-schools-ploy-educators-should-be-sacked-over-move-peter-dutton-says/news-story/2331f46d7d432904ce0aa5fbf3dfa234 |title='Sack them' call on Safe-Schools plot |author=Baxendale, Rachel|date=17 August 2017|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref>
In December 2017 NSW Opposition Leader, [[Luke Foley]] said that the Safe Schools program will "never return" under a Labor government.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/blogs/miranda-devine/miranda-live-safe-schools-gone-for-good-says-luke-foley/news-story/cb715bf0080519a3fe552129205267e6 |title=Miranda Live: Safe Schools ‘gone for good’ says Luke Foley |author=Devine, Miranda |date=20 December 2017|work=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=21 December 2017}}</ref>
===Victoria=== In March 2016, following the Louden Review, the Victorian Premier [[Daniel Andrews]] took issue that students will now require parental permission to attend the Safe Schools program. He "vowed to defend its place in every Victorian secondary school", while the NSW Premier [[Mike Baird]] disagreed, saying "parental engagement is a good thing."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/education/safe-schools-nsw-premier-mike-baird-defends-federal-governments-review-20160322-gno9si.html |title=Safe Schools: NSW Premier Mike Baird defends federal government's review |author=Bagshaw, Eric|date=22 March 2016|work=Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=26 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3503968/Mike-Baird-defends-overhaul-Safe-Schools-educating-students-LGBT-issues.html |title='How on earth can our children be looking at this?': NSW premier Mike Baird weighs in on changes to Safe Schools program aimed at educating children on LGTBI issues |author=Eddie, Rachel|date=22 March 2016|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=26 March 2016}}</ref>
On 15 May 2016, it was reported that the Victorian Government will spend about $1 million of its own funds to run the Safe Schools Program and will include those elements dropped by the Federal Government. They have subsequently added new links to optional resources from The Gayby Project<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.education.vic.gov.au/about/programs/health/Pages/safe-schools-coalition.aspx|title=Safe Schools Coalition Victoria|last=|first=|date=2 June 2016|website=Victorian Department of Education and Training|publisher=Victorian Department of Education and Training|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref> produced by the makers of the Australian documentary film ''[[Gayby Baby]]'' for students in grade five to year 10.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/preelection-hostilities-reignite-over-safe-schools-program-20160513-gov2rs.html |title=Safe Schools: Pre-election hostilities reignite over |author=Tomazin, Farrah|date=15 May 2016|work=[[The Age]]|accessdate=15 May 2016}}</ref><ref name = "SSC Gayby Baby">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/gayby-baby-schools-to-get-a-lesson-in-family-diversity-20160507-goouoe.html |title=Gayby Baby: schools to get a lesson in family diversity |author=Tomazin, Farrah|date=8 May 2016|work=[[The Age]]|accessdate=15 May 2016}}</ref> All state secondary schools in Victoria are to be members of the SSCA by 2018.<ref name="cpda">{{Cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com.au/2016/04/12/vic-premier-daniel-andrews-commits-to-expanding-safe-schools-coa/ |title=VIC Premier Daniel Andrews Commits To Expanding Safe Schools Coalition In His State |author= |accessdate=20 September 2016 |date=12 April 2016 |work=he Huffington Post Australia }}</ref>
In December 2016 Safe Schools Coalition Australia has severed its ties with the Safe Schools Coalition Victoria.<ref name= "SSCV">{{cite web|url=https://sscv.org.au/ |title=Safe Schools Coalition Victoria |work=Safe Schools Coalition Victoria |accessdate=3 December 2016}}</ref><ref name= "DESPOGI">{{cite news|url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/push-in-schools-to-fight-modern-homophobia/news-story/d2ecf868fd342b721dee22e543c34001 |title=Push in schools to fight ‘modern’ homophobia |author=Urban, Rebecca|date=2 December 2016|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=3 December 2016}}</ref><ref name = "SSCV2"/>
In December 2016, the Victorian Government said it will take responsibility for and "overhaul" the Safe Schools program, with the government cutting its ties with both Ward<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/safe-schools-program-to-be-overhauled-and-founder-roz-ward-removed-20161216-gtctgs.html |title=Safe Schools program to be overhauled and founder Roz Ward removed |author=Tomazin, Farrah|date=16 December 2016|work=[[The Age]]|accessdate=17 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.outinperth.com/victorian-government-announces-overhaul-safe-schools-program/ |title=Victorian government announces overhaul of Safe Schools program |date=16 December 2016|work=[[OutInPerth]]|accessdate=17 December 2016}}</ref> and Latrobe University.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/daniel-andrews-cuts-la-trobe-uni-from-safe-schools-program/news-story/b38723a260e7bf25e9b0fc7c76914df4 |title=Daniel Andrews cuts La Trobe uni from Safe Schools program |author=Ferguson, John|date=17 December 2016|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=17 December 2016}}</ref> In January 2017, it was reported that a new Victorian manager is to be appointed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/safe-schools-victoria-head-could-pocket-almost-300k-over-two-years/news-story/9b572624c79242ab66fd198ecd8b3b42 |title=Safe Schools Victoria head could pocket almost $300k over two years |author=White, Alex|date=17 January 2017|work=[[The Courier-Mail]]|accessdate=18 January 2017}}</ref>
The Victorian government has pledged to fully fund the program in Victoria,<ref name = "SSC contact"/> and has established Safe Schools Victoria.<ref name = "SSV">{{cite web|url= http://www.education.vic.gov.au/about/programs/health/Pages/safe-schools-coalition.aspx |title= Safe Schools (Victoria)|work=[[Department of Education and Training (Victoria)|Education Deptartment Victoria]]|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> The Victorian opposition education spokesman [[Tim Smith (Australian politician)|Tim Smith]] has said, if elected, he would replace the program with a broader anti-bullying program,<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/jan/24/victorian-opposition-vows-to-scrap-safe-schools-and-teach-western-principles |title=Victorian opposition vows to scrap Safe Schools and teach 'western' principles |date =25 January 2018}}</ref> as NSW has done.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/labor-split-on-safe-schools-future/news-story/5a5abea693d0719f3596f1a143c59d06 |title= Labor split on Safe Schools future|author=Hutchinson, Samantha|date=26 December 2017|work=The Australian|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/simon-birmingham-backs-victorian-libs-push-for-australian-values-in-schools/news-story/335ed5dea9d4963d0d10e0ede3f21bca |title=Simon Birmingham backs Victorian Libs’ push for ‘Australian values’ in schools |date =25 January 2018 }}</ref>
In February 2018 a petition against Safe Schools was signed by 16,000 Victorians.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/antisafe-schools-petition-signed-by-16000-victorians/news-story/00fc892446430b7b2acb5b6c541be1cb |title=Anti-Safe Schools petition signed by 16,000 Victorians |date =10 February 2016 }}</ref>
===Queensland=== The program began in Queensland from the start of the second semester in 2015. [[Annastacia Palaszczuk]] pledged support for Safe Schools during the [[Queensland state election, 2015|2015 Queensland state election]] but as of March 2016 had not made any announcements.<ref name="sgao"/>
In September 2016, Queensland students were told not to participate in any class lessons involving Safe Schools Coalition materials without the consent of their parents.<ref name = "parent view"/>
In June 2017, the Queensland Government announced that it will not fund the program when the federal Government ceases funding the Safe Schools Program in October 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-06-23/queensland-safe-schools-funding-will-not-continue-post-october/8642966 |title=Safe Schools: Queensland Government will not fund teacher training after October |author=Wiggins, Nick|date=23 June 2017|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref> Queensland has withdrawn from the Safe Schools Coalition Program.<ref name ="July 2017"/> The [[Liberal National Party of Queensland|Liberal National Party]] has said, in September 2017, if they are elected to form government they will, "dump the Safe Schools program".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/education/an-elected-lnp-government-would-dump-safe-schools-in-queensland-20170913-p4yvw8 |title=An elected LNP government would dump Safe Schools in Queensland |date=13 September 2017|work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref>
In September 2017 there was what was described as "aggressive altercations" to prevent people entering a Brisbane church where a Safe Schools seminar was being held.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.outinperth.com/confrontational-protests-safe-schools-brisbane-church/ |title=Confrontational protests over Safe Schools at Brisbane Church |date=8 September 2017|work=[[OutInPerth]]|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> A police statement and camera footage do not support the protesters version of what took place, saying, "there was no record of any cars hurtling towards protesters, nor any other assault or injury".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/the-ugly-samesex-clash-at-brisbane-church-that-proved-quite-tame/news-story/0a5db9f89a7f0abddea0dd8d8cffabc6 |title= The ‘ugly’ same-sex clash that wasn’t|author=Schliebs, Mark|date=9 September 2017|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref>
===South Australia=== The South Australian Education Minister lamented the federal government's response to the successful program,<ref name="sgao"/> which was launched in that state on 13 June 2014.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} In September 2016, South Australian students were told not to participate in any class lessons involving Safe Schools Coalition materials without the consent of their parents.<ref name = "parent view"/> South Australia is to develop its own programs, abandoning the national Safe Schools scheme.<ref name="SA position">{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/ward-departs-la-trobe-following-programs-scrapping/news-story/fbf7624b707d861b8a1bb3e9b16e903b |title=Ward departs La Trobe following program’s scrapping |author=Urban, Rebecca|work=[[The Australian]]|date=19 June 2017 |accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref> South Australia has withdrawn from the Safe Schools Coalition Program.<ref name ="July 2017"/> The South Australian opposition said it will replace the Safe Schools program if elected.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/jan/17/south-australian-coalition-vow-to-scrap-safe-schools-program-if-it-wins-state-election |title=South Australian Liberals vow to scrap version of Safe Schools if they win election |date = 17 January 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.sbs.com.au/news/sa-libs-to-scrap-safe-schools-program |title=SA Libs to scrap safe schools program |date =16 January 2018 }}</ref>
===Western Australia=== In September 2016, Western Australian students were told not to participate in any class lessons involving Safe Schools Coalition materials without the consent of their parents.<ref name = "parent view"/>
===Tasmania=== In 2016 the Safe Schools Program was "rolled out" in 20 Tasmanian schools.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-11-05/tasmanian-liberals-vote-to-ditch-safe-schools-program/7998100 |title=Tasmanian Liberals vote to ditch 'disgusting, belligerent' Safe Schools program |date=5 November 2016|work=ABC}}</ref> In April 2017 it was reported that Tasmania will scrap its support for the Safe Schools program, replacing it with a comprehensive anti-bullying scheme.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/safe-schools-antibully-project-to-lose-tasmania-funding/news-story/edf86542522560f86061f7fa209fe67d |title=Safe Schools’ anti-bully project to lose Tasmania funding |author=Urban, Rebecca|date=18 April 2017|work=The Australian|accessdate=18 April 2017}}</ref>
===Australian Capital Territory=== In August 2016, the [[Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory|ACT Chief Minister]], [[Andrew Barr]], committed $100,000 to the Safe Schools Program in the Territory.<ref name= "ACT">{{cite news|url= http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/act-stumps-up-100000-to-ensure-safe-schools-program-does-not-fail-20160826-gr21c0.html |title=ACT stumps up $100,000 to ensure Safe Schools program does not fail |author=Knaus, Christopher|date=26 August 2016|work=[[Canberra Times]]|accessdate=26 August 2016}}</ref> ''The Australian'' newspaper reported that this would enable restrictions imposed on the national scheme to be circumvented.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/safe-schools-act-to-fund-program-at-canberra-schools/news-story/5134f49fd32961d2ce384f330940ddc3 |title=Safe Schools: ACT to fund program at Canberra schools |author=Owens, Jared|date=26 August 2016|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=26 August 2016}}</ref>
The ACT government has pledged to fully fund the program in the ACT<ref name = "SSC contact"/> and is developing a program for "sexually and gender diverse students, staff and families".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/contract-signed-for-canberraspecific-safe-schools-program-20170217-guffez.html |title= Contract signed for Canberra-specific 'Safe Schools' program |author=Baker, Emily|date=20 February 2017|work=Canberra Times|accessdate=17 April 2017}}</ref> As of 2017 the ACT is no longer a member of the Safe Schools Coalition Program.<ref name ="July 2017"/> The new program will have a change of name with the ACT [[Yvette Berry|Education Minister]] saying it, "won't be defined as a program because then that implies that you're delivering a class or a program on something".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/canberra-liberals-question-act-safe-schools-plans-20170630-gx226y.html |title=Canberra Liberals question ACT Safe Schools plans |author=Baker, Emily|date=30 June 2017|work=[[The Canberra Times]]|accessdate=5 July 2017}}</ref>
In August 2017 Liberal politician [[Elizabeth Kikkert]] speaking in the [[ACT Legislative Assembly]] said that "13-year-old girls [were asked] to fantasise about sexual intercourse". Opposition education spokesman [[Andrew Wall]] tabled a petition and asked the ACT government to withdraw support for the program. In response, [[Deputy Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory|Deputy Chief Minister]], [[Yvette Berry]] said Mr Wall should be "ashamed of himself" for bringing the petition forward.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-08-24/canberra-liberal-says-students-being-groomed-by-safe-schools/8840158 |title=Canberra Liberal claims Safe Schools program asks students to fantasise about same gender |author= Sibthorpe, Claire|date=24 August 2017|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|accessdate=25 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.watoday.com.au/act-news/liberals-elizabeth-kikkert-says-children-being-groomed-by-safe-schools-program-20170824-gy2y2x.html |title=Liberals Elizabeth Kikkert says children being 'groomed' by Safe Schools program |author=Burgess, Kate|date=24 August 2017|work=WA Today|accessdate=25 August 2017}}</ref>
In September 2017 it was reported that Education Minister [[Yvette Berry]], "will soon launch" the ACT's answer to Safe Schools program.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/act-education-minister-yvette-berry-cautions-schools-on-samesex-marriage-20170920-gyl17m.html |title=ACT Education Minister Yvette Berry cautions schools on same-sex marriage|author=Baker. Emily|work=[[The Canberra Times]]|date=21 September 2017|accessdate=22 September 2017}}</ref>
===Northern Territory=== One Northern Territory school has signed up for the program.<ref name ="July 2017"/>
==See also== {{Portal|Australia|Education|LGBT|Transgender}} * [[Education in Australia]] * ''[[Gayby Baby]]'' * [[Kids Helpline]] * {{slink|La Trobe University|Controversies}} * [[LGBT rights in Australia]] * [[National School Chaplaincy Programme]] * [[Suicide among LGBT youth]] * ''[[The Gender Fairy]]'' * [[Wear it Purple Day]]
{{Clear}}

revision.comment: Made it clear that the research on Gaelic medium education take up and continued use is suggestive and not definite (original wording suggested definite) and further research underway to quantify this
revision.text:
{{redirect|Gaelic medium education|other uses}} [[File:Sgoil Ghàidhlig Ghlaschu.jpg|thumb|right|{{lang|gd|Sgoil Ghàidhlig Ghlaschu}}, or [[Glasgow Gaelic School]], is the largest provider of Gaelic medium education in Scotland in terms of pupils]] '''Gaelic medium education''' ('''G.M.E.''' or '''GME'''; {{lang-gd|Foghlam tro Mheadhan na Gàidhlig}}) is a form of [[education in Scotland]] that allows pupils to be taught primarily through the medium of Scottish Gaelic, with [[English language|English]] being taught as the secondary language. Gaelic medium education is increasingly popular throughout Scotland, and the number of pupils who are in Gaelic medium education has risen from 24 in 1985 (its first year){{cite web|title=Scotland's Languages: Gaelic|url=http://www.educationscotland.gov.uk/studyingscotland/resourcesforlearning/literaturelanguage/scotlandslanguages/gaelic.asp|website=Education Scotland|accessdate=23 June 2014}} to 3,892 in 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gov.scot/Topics/Statistics/Browse/School-Education/dspupcensus/dspupcensus16|title=Pupil census 2016 supplementary data|last=ceu@scotland.gsi.gov.uk|first=Scottish Government, St. Andrew's House, Regent Road, Edinburgh EH1 3DG Tel:0131 556 8400|date=2016-12-12|website=www.gov.scot|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-04-28}} The current figure is the highest number of Gaelic medium Education pupils in Scotland since the 2005 passage of the [[Gaelic Language (Scotland) Act 2005|Gaelic Language (Scotland) Act]] by the [[Scottish Parliament]]. Not included in this figure are university students at {{lang|gd|[[Sabhal Mòr Ostaig]]}}, [[Lews Castle College]], or {{lang|gd|[[Ionad Chaluim Chille Ìle]]}} who are taking their degrees through the medium of Gaelic.{{cite news|url=http://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/news-and-diary/hrh-visits-sabhal-mor-ostaig-scotlands-only-gaelic-language-college|publisher=Prince of Wales|title=HRH visits Sabhal Mor Ostaig, Scotland's only Gaelic language college|date=5 December 2015}}{{cite web|title=Gàidhlig agus Conaltradh Certhe |url=https://www.lews.uhi.ac.uk/courses/certhe-gaidhlig-agus-conaltradh|website=Lews Castle College|publisher=University of Highlands and Islands |accessdate=15 January 2017|language=gd}}{{cite web|title=About us|url=http://en.islay-gaelic.net/pagex.asp?bioid=33051 |website=Ionad Chaluim Chille Ìle |accessdate=7 January 2017 }} However, some research has suggested that Gaelic medium education by itself is not enough for full bilingual competency in Gaelic, and it may be the pupils in primary Gaelic education who go on to use the language frequently as adults is limited.{{cite web|last1=Wilson McLeod, University of Edinburgh Bernadette O’Rourke, Heriot-Watt University Stuart Dunmore, University of Edinburgh|title=‘New Speakers’ of Gaelic in Edinburgh and Glasgow|url=http://www.soillse.ac.uk/wp-content/uploads/New-Speakers’-of-Gaelic-in-Edinburgh-and-Glasgow.pdf|website=Soillse|accessdate=13 January 2017}}. Further qualitative and quantitative research is underway to articulate take up and the impact of changing strategies over time. ==Current provision== In 2016, 10,215 pupils in Scotland were receiving some kind of education in Gaelic representing 1.5% of the country's student population. This figure is higher than Scotland's overall proportion of Gaelic speakers which stood at 1.1% in 2011. Nearly 3,900 students in Scotland were enrolled in Gaelic medium education in 2016, a 32% increase in only three years and a 47% increase over 2010 figures.{{cite web|title=Pupil Census Supplementary Data|url=http://www.gov.scot/Topics/Statistics/Browse/School-Education/dspupcensus/|publisher=The Scottish Government|accessdate=16 October 2017}} {| class="wikitable" style="align:center" |- ! !! !! Number of Pupils !! As a percentage of all
pupils in Scotland
at that level |- ! rowspan="3" | Gaelic-medium
education | Secondary pupils || 842 || 0.30% |- | Primary pupils || 3,050 || 0.77% |- ! '''ALL PUPILS || '''3,892 || '''0.58%''' |} Six council areas had a higher than average enrollment of students in Gaelic Medium Education: [[Eilean Siar]] (27.16%); [[Highland (council area)|Highland]] (3.69%); [[Argyll & Bute]] (1.80%); [[Glasgow|Glasgow City]] (1.18%); [[Edinburgh|Edinburgh City]] (0.76%); and [[Stirling (council area)|Stirling]] (0.61%). Over 6,300 other pupils in Scotland were receiving instruction in Gaelic language courses in 2016.[http://www.gov.scot/Topics/Statistics/Browse/School-Education/dspupcensus/dspupcensus16 Pupil census 2016 supplementary data]; updated 17 May 2017 {| class="wikitable" style="align:center" |- ! !! !! Number of Pupils !! As a percentage of all
pupils in Scotland
at that level |- ! Gaelic the only subject
taught through Gaelic | Secondary pupils || 268 || 0.10% |- ! rowspan="3" | Gaelic learner classes | Secondary pupils || 2,473 || 0.88% |- | Primary pupils || 3,582 || 0.90% |- ! '''ALL PUPILS || '''6,055 || '''0.89%''' |- ! colspan="2" | TOTAL !! 6,323 !! 0.93% |} In [[Eilean Siar]], 86.19% of all pupils were receiving some form of Gaelic-language education in 2016. In second place was [[Argyll & Bute]] at 10.75%, with the [[Highland (council area)|Highland]] council area in third at 7.59%. On the reverse side, sixteen council areas had no students at all receiving any education in Gaelic. [[File:Bunsgoilbh copy.jpg|thumb|right|Bun-Sgoil Bharabhais is an example of a [[Primary School]] containing a Gaelic Medium Unit]] There are a handful of dedicated Gaelic medium schools in the country. The largest is [[Sgoil Ghàidhlig Ghlaschu]][http://www.glasgow.gov.uk/en/Residents/GoingtoSchool/GaelicEducation/ Gaelic Education] (Glasgow Gaelic School), established in 2006 and catering to pupils aged three to eighteen, the country's first 3-18 Gaelic medium school.{{cite web|last1=O'Connor|first1=Ronnie|title=Follow Through Inspection Report: Glasgow Gaelic Primary School|url=http://www.glasgow.gov.uk/CHttpHandler.ashx?id=11969&p=0|website=Glasgow City Council|publisher=Glasgow City Council|accessdate=23 June 2014}} At the beginning of the 2015-16 year the school enrolled 811 pupils and is one of the most over-enrolled schools in Scotland.{{cite web|title=School Estates 2016 supplementary dataset|url=http://www.gov.scot/Topics/Statistics/Browse/School-Education/schoolestatestats/schestate2016|website=The Scottish Government|accessdate=12 December 2016}} The country's only other Gaelic medium secondary school is Sgoil Lionacleit on the island of [[Benbecula]] in Na h-Eileanan Siar. Several Gaelic language primary schools exist in the Western Isles. Outside that region, [[Bun-sgoil Ghàidhlig Inbhir Nis]] opened in 2007 in Inverness and serves pupils in class 1-7,https://bunsgoilghaidhliginbhirnis.wordpress.com/about/ as does [[Bun-sgoil Taobh na Pàirce]] which opened in 2013 in the capital city of Edinburgh. A new Gaelic medium primary school, [[Bun-sgoil Ghàidhlig Loch Abar]], opened in [[Caol]] near Fort William in 2015, and a similar school is currently under construction in [[Portree]].{{cite news|title=Construction begins on Portree Gaelic primary school|url=http://www.urbanrealm.com/news/6375/Construction_begins_on_Portree_Gaelic_primary_school_.html|accessdate=16 October 2017|work=Urban Realm|date=14 September 2015}} As there are still relatively few [[List of schools providing Gaelic medium education in Scotland|such schools]], however, Gaelic medium education is mainly provided through Gaelic medium units within English-speaking schools. [[Bun-sgoil Shlèite]] on the [[Skye|Isle of Skye]] is the exception in that it is a Gaelic school with an English Medium Unit. The largest Gaelic unit is at [[Mount Cameron Primary School]] in [[East Kilbride]] which enrolled 70 pupils at the start of the 2015-16 school year.{{cite web|title=School Estates 2016 supplementary dataset|url=http://www.gov.scot/Topics/Statistics/Browse/School-Education/schoolestatestats/schestate2016|website=The Scottish Government|accessdate=16 October 2017}} ===Effectiveness=== Several studies have examined the Gaelic-language capabilities of Gaelic-medium educated adults and found that few of them demonstrate native-like, or fully bilingual, abilities in Gaelic:
"researchers in these studies [(cf. Landgraf 2013; Nance 2013; MacLeod et al. 2014). Landgraf (2013) and Macleod et al. (2014)] observed '''frequent and unmarked use of non-native-like features''' in GME students’ syntax, morphology and phonology, both through ethnographic observations in the classroom and individual interviews."Dunmore, Stuart. "Bilingual life after school? Language use, ideologies and attitudes among Gaelic-medium educated adults." (2015). Pg. 80. ''(emphasis added)''
In her 2013 thesis, Julia Landgraf found that the few GME students exhibiting fully bilingual abilities came from Gaelic-speaking households.Landgraf, Julia (Sìleas). Cànain agus Cultar ann am Foghlam tro Mheadhan na Gàidhlig: Neartan, Duilgheadasan agus am Buaidh air Comasan is Seasamhan Cànain na h-Òlgridh. Diss. University of Aberdeen, 2013. However, GME students and other young adults from Gaelic-speaking areas are increasingly exhibiting English-influenced phonology.Nance, C. (2014). Phonetic variation in Scottish Gaelic laterals. Journal of Phonetics, 47, 1-17. Furthermore, not all graduates end up using the language. In Dunmore's study of 46 adults from a GME background, a majority were classified as "low use." Usage was strongly correlated with language abilities.Dunmore, Stuart. "Bilingual life after school? Language use, ideologies and attitudes among Gaelic-medium educated adults." (2015). Pg. 136. ==History== ===17th century=== The attitudes towards education and the promotion of Anglicisation have been described as resulting from "confrontation of two disparate societies...Lowland Scotland made plain its anxiety concerning the unreformed society in the north in terms of unease concerning its language, which was identified as the chief cause of barbarity, ignorance and popery"MacKinnon, Kenneth Gaelic: A Past and Future Prospect (pp56) and can be seen as a continuation of such policies going back to 1609 and the [[Statutes of Iona]] which saw the Gaelic speaking nobility of Scotland forced to send their children to be educated in English speaking [[Lowland Scotland]]; an act which has been described as "the first of a succession of measures taken by the Scottish government specifically aimed at the extirpation of the Gaelic language, the destruction of its traditional culture and the suppression of its bearers."MacKinnon, Kenneth ''Gaelic: A Past and Future Prospect'' (pp46) This was followed in 1616 by an act of the [[privy council]] which included a requirement that the children of the [[Scottish Highlands|Highland]] nobility must be capable of speaking, reading and writing English if they were to be recognised as heirs.Hutchison, Roger ''Gealach an Fhàis: Ùr Beothachadh na Gàidhlig'' (pp50) ===18th century=== The history of Gaelic language schools (in the modern sense) in [[Scotland]] can be traced back to the early 18th century and the schools of the [[Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge|Scottish Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge]] or SSPCK. Ironically, one of the primary aims of the society was the de-[[Gaelicisation]] of the Highlands and initially its schools taught exclusively through the medium of the English language with the equivalent use of Gaelic prohibited.MacKinnon, Kenneth ''Gaelic: A Past and Future Prospect'' (pp54) However the insistence on teaching children in a language which was (in almost all cases) entirely foreign to them resulted in very little progress with regards to establishing literacy in the English language. This situation persisted until the collapse of the [[Jacobitism|Jacobite]] cause in 1746 with the [[Battle of Culloden]] and the consequent collapse of the Gaelic speaking political structures and the pacification of the Highlands by the [[British Army]] in the ensuing decades. The change in political atmosphere following the [[Disarming Act]], as well as campaigning by the likes of [[Samuel Johnson]] - who was aghast at the fact the SSPCK was actively preventing the publication of the [[Bible]] into Scottish Gaelic — led to the change in attitudes within the Society. Johnson had to say of the matter: :"...there remains only their language and their poverty. Their language is attacked on every side. Schools are erected in which English only is taught and there were lately some who thought it reasonable to refuse them a version of the Holy Scriptures, that they might have no monument to their mother tongue."MacKinnon, Kenneth ''Gaelic: A Past and Future Prospect'' (pp55) Johnson, despite being commonly viewed as both anti-Scottish and anti-Gaelic, was actively involved in campaigning for the production of Gaelic literature and proposed the creation of a Gaelic press in the [[Isle of Skye]].MacKinnon, Kenneth ''Gaelic: A Past and Future Prospect'' (pp56) The change in attitudes resulted in the production, by the SSPCK, of a Gaelic version of the [[New Testament]] in 1767 with the [[Old Testament]] being translated and published in 1801. 1767 also saw the SSPCK switch from English to [[Gaelic language|Gaelic]] as the language of instruction in their Highland schools. A school in Inverness, [[Raining School]], was also established to provide training for Gaelic speaking teachers.Hutchison, Roger ''Gealach an Fhàis: Ùr Beothachadh na Gàidhlig'' (pp51) ===19th century=== The 19th century saw the establishment of the first Gaelic school society — the ''Edinburgh Society for the Support of Gaelic Schools'' - in 1811.Thomson, Derick S. ''The Companion to Gaelic Scotland'' (pp258) The society stated its purpose thus: :"(the) sole object being to teach the inhabitants of the [[Highlands and Islands]] to read the Sacred Scriptures in their native tongue...to maintain Circulating Schools in which the Gaelic language only shall be taught." The new society attracted much support with similar organisations being founded in [[Glasgow]] and [[Inverness]]. The early success of the Edinburgh society was such that by 1828 it funded 85 schools in the Highlands and Islands with its sister societies enjoying similar levels of success. However following the early period of success the groups encountered financial difficulties due to poor administration and started to decline around 1830 and by 1850 only the original [[Edinburgh]] society remained although this branch, with strong support from the [[Edinburgh Ladies Association]], continued until 1892. This was despite the introduction of the [[Education (Scotland) Act 1872]] which effectively put an end to non-English medium education and led to the discouragement of Gaelic with pupils being punished by teachers for speaking the language.{{cite web |url=https://openaccess.leidenuniv.nl/bitstream/handle/1887/18678/Language%20shift%20on%20Skye%20-%20printed%20version.pdf?sequence=2 |title=Gaelic Language Erosion and Revitalization on the Isle of Skye, Scotland |first1=Dick |last1=Smakman |first2=Cassandra |last2=Smith-Christmas |publisher=openaccess.leidenuniv.nl}} The effect of the education act upon the Gaelic language has been described as "disastrous"[https://books.google.com/books?id=0ldowI6VgeMC&pg=PA568&lpg=PA568&dq=gaelic+education+act+1872&source=web&ots=Bs9xcVrday&sig=eZEmZf9KIEbEEfoKq4celdsqBYw&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=4&ct=result The Edinburgh history of the Scots language], ''Charles Jones''. Retrieved from Google Books on 22 November 2011. and the continuation of a general policy (by both [[Parliament of Scotland|Scottish]], and post [[Acts of Union 1707|1707]], [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|British]]) which aimed at [[Anglicisation]]. Pressure upon the Scottish Education Department in the years immediately following the act of 1872 saw the gradual reintroduction of certain measures providing for the use of Gaelic in schools.Thomson, Derick S. ''The Companion to Gaelic Scotland'' (pp259) This pressure led to the undertaking by the department of a survey in 1876 which revealed a "distinct majority" of school boards within the Highlands in favour of the inclusion of Gaelic within the curriculum although it also revealed that some of those in Gaelic-speaking areas were against this. However the continuing reluctance of school boards to take full advantages of the limited provisions made for Gaelic within the school curriculum as well as the problems of financing the Education Act generally saw little use of the limited provisions for Gaelic within the schools.Thomson, Derick S. ''The Companion to Gaelic Scotland'' (pp260) The severe financial difficulties suffered by Highland schools at this time saw the introduction of the "[[Highland Minute]]" in 1887 which aimed at aiding designated boards financially while also recognising Gaelic as a specific subject in the higher classes of both elementary and secondary schools. Grants to aid the supply of Gaelic speaking teachers were also introduced. Despite these small measures towards the reintroduction of Gaelic into the classroom the manner in which the language was taught is thought to have contributed to its decline with the language being taught not as the native tongue of the pupils, via the medium of the language itself, but as an academic subject to be studied only through the English language with ever decreasing numbers of students studying the language. ==See also== * [[Clì Gàidhlig]] - organization supporting learners of the Gaelic language * [[Comann nam Pàrant]] - organization supporting parents of GME students ==Notes== {{Reflist|2}} ==References== * Thomson, Derick S. ''The Companion to Gaelic Scotland'', (Blackwell Reference 1987), {{ISBN|0-631-15578-3}} * MacKinnon, Kenneth ''Gaelic: A Past and Future Prospect'' (Saltire Society 1991), {{ISBN|978-0-85411-047-6}} * Hutchison, Roger ''Gealach an Fhàis: Ùr Beothachadh na Gàidhlig'' (Mainstream Publishing 2005), {{ISBN|978-1-84018-999-5}} * Jones, Charles ''The Edinburgh History of the Scots Language'' (Edinburgh University Press), {{ISBN|0-7486-0754-4}} ==External links== * [http://www.gaelicteaching.com/en/ gaelicteaching.com] - Information on Gaelic teaching for teachers, students and pupils. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130730110519/http://www.gaidhlig.org.uk/Downloads/Rannsachadh/CR10-13%20%20Data%20Foghlaim%202010-11%20Beurla.pdf Gaelic pupils numbers] - Information on numbers of gaelic pupils per school {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Celtic languages}} {{Scottish education}} [[Category:Education in Scotland]] [[Category:Minority schools]] [[Category:Scottish Gaelic education]] [[Category:Medium of instruction]] [[Category:Language education in the United Kingdom]]

'''Shih-Hui Chen''' (陳士惠) (born 1962) is a [[Taiwan]]ese composer who lives and works in the [[United States]]. [[File:Shih-Hui Chen.jpg|thumb|Composer Shih-Hui Chen]]
==Biography== Chen Shih-hui (陳士惠) was born in [[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]], and came to the United States in 1982 to study for a master's degree from [[Northern Illinois University]] and a doctoral degree from [[Boston University]].<ref>Mittler, Barbara. ''Chen Shihui.'' Grove Music Online. Oxford Music Online {{subscription}} (Online version of ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians]]'', 2nd edition. {{ISBN|978-0-19-517067-2}}).</ref> After receiving her DMA in Music Composition, Shih-Hui Chen took a position at the Shepherd School of Music, [[Rice University]] <ref>{{cite book |title=Dangerous tunes: the politics of Chinese music in Hong Kong, Taiwan and the People's Republic of China since 1949|author=Mittler, Barbara|year=1997}}</ref> where she is currently an Associate Professor of Music Composition. She served as composer-in-residence at Boston University's Tanglewood Institute in 2000, 2001 and 2004, and as music advisor for the Formosa Chamber Music Society. She is a former member of the composers' collective Musiqa and the Asian Composers' League.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bmop.org/explore-bmop/musicians/shih-hui-chen|title=Shih-hui Chen|accessdate=22 June 2011}}</ref>
Chen Shih-hui has been awarded a number of grants, and her work has been performed internationally. In 1999, she received an American Academy in [[Rome Prize]], a [[Guggenheim Fellowship]] in 2000, and a Goddard Lieberson Fellowship from the [[American Academy of Arts and Letters]] in 2007. In 2010, Chen received a [[Fulbright Fellowship]] to study traditional Chinese Music, [[Nanguan music]], and music of the [[Taiwanese aboriginal]] people.
==Works== Chen Shih-hui composes for orchestra, chamber ensemble, voice, and solo instruments. She also composes music for theater and film scores.<ref>{{cite book |url=|title=Film review: Special: Issues 55-56|year=2005}}</ref>
Selected works include: *''66 Times'' for Soprano and Chamber Ensemble *''66 Times'' for Soprano and Chamber Orchestra *''Fu I'' for Solo Pipa *''Fu II'' for Pipa and Five Western Instruments *''Mei Hua'' for String Quartet *''Moments'' for Full Orchestra *''Plum Blossoms'' for Alto Saxophone and Piano *''Shui'' for Cello and Piano *''Remembrance'' (思想起中提琴協奏曲 ''Shu Shon Key'') for viola and chamber ensemble (2006) or for viola and chamber orchestra (2006) *''Sweet Rice Pie, Six Songs on Four Taiwanese Nursery Rhymes'' for Voice and Chamber Ensemble *''Twice Removed'' for Solo Alto Saxophone and Solo Clarinet (2 versions)
==References== {{reflist}}
== Official link == *[http://www.shihhuichen.com Composer's Website]
{{authority control}}

1994 | Ship launched = September 4, 1999 | Ship acquired = | Ship commissioned = June 25, 2000 | Ship decommissioned = | Ship in service = | Ship out of service = | Ship struck = | Ship reinstated = | Ship identification=*{{MMSI Number|273452840}} *[[Maritime call sign|Callsign]]: UAEM | Ship honours = | Ship fate = | Ship status = | Ship notes = }} {{Infobox ship characteristics | Hide header = | Header caption = (typical) | Ship class = replica 28-gun frigate, | Ship displacement = 220 [[ton]]s<ref name="Ship Characteristics">{{cite web|url=http://www.shtandart.ru/content/view/47/431/|title=Ship Characteristics|publisher=Shtandart|language=ru|accessdate=2009-09-11}}</ref> | Ship length =*{{convert|34.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} ([[Length overall|Overall]]),<ref name="Ship Characteristics" /> *{{convert|25.88|m|ft|abbr=on}} ([[Length deck center line|registered length]])<ref name="Ship Characteristics" /> | Ship beam = {{convert|7.0|m|ft|abbr=on}}<ref name="Ship Characteristics" /> | Ship draught = | Ship draft = {{convert|3.0-3.3|m|ft|abbr=on}}<ref name="Ship Characteristics" /> | Ship height = {{convert|33|m|ft|abbr=on}} [[Mast (sailing)|mainmast]]<ref name="Ship Characteristics" /> | Ship propulsion =*Sail (three masts, [[Full rigged ship|ship rig]]), *1999: add 2 х [[Volvo Penta]] TAMD 122P, {{Convert|560|hp|kW|abbr=on|lk=in}} | Ship speed = {{convert|11|kn|km/h|lk=in}} | Ship sail plan = {{convert|620|m2|sqft|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} on three masts<ref name="Ship Characteristics" /> | Ship decks = [[Berth (sleeping)|Berth]], [[Gun deck|Gun]], [[Spar (sailing)|Spar]] | Ship range = | Ship complement =*1703: 120 [[seamen]], *1999: 40 seamen | Ship sensors = | Ship EW = | Ship armament = 7 modern saluting guns (original of 1703 had 28 guns) | Ship armour = | Ship armor = | Ship aircraft = | Ship aircraft facilities = | Ship notes = }} |} The [[frigate]] '''''Shtandart''''' (''{{Lang-ru|Штандартъ}}'') is modern replica of the [[Shtandart (frigate)|first ship]] of Russia's [[Baltic fleet]], was launched in 1703 at the Olonetsky shipyard near [[Olonets]] by the decree of [[Tsar]] [[Peter I of Russia|Peter I]] and orders issued by commander [[Aleksandr Danilovich Menshikov|Aleksandr Menshikov]]. The name ''Shtandart'' was also given to the royal yachts of the tsars until the [[Russian Revolution (1917)|Russian Revolution in 1917]]. Tsar [[Nicholas II of Russia|Nicholas II's]] royal yacht was last of this series.
== Design == In 1994 a small group of sailing enthusiasts led by Vladimir Martus started construction of a replica of the [[Shtandart (frigate)|historical ship]]. Martus developed a new layout of the ''Shtandart'' wherein she was built with four bulkheads, dividing her into five compartments.
The replica frigate has three masts and her displacement is 220 tons. She is 25.88 metres (82.0 ft) registered length, 27.5 metres (90 ft) long on deck and 34.5 metres (113 ft) long overall. The ''Shtandart'' is 7.0 metres (23 ft) wide with a draft of 3.0 to 3.3 metres (11 ft). The ship is designed for speeds between 8-9 knots under sail, and under auxiliary engines she can make up to 13 knots (25 km/h). The original crew complement in 1703 was between 120 and 150, and the modern crew consists of 30 trainees and 10 officers.
The "Shtandart Project" (a non-commercial organisation dedicated to youth development) launched a replica of the frigate on September 4, 1999. The modern ''Shtandart'' has two zones: * The historically accurate area above the [[gun deck]]: the [[Steering wheel (ship)|steering wheel]] and helm, all decorative carvings, the furniture, and all of the [[Mast (sailing)|masts]], [[Touch hole|spikes]], [[guns]], gangways and hatches are carefully reconstructed. * The "modern" area built to modern standards and in compliance with safety regulations: This includes two [[Volvo Penta]] TAMD 122P engines and a generator. [[File:Alyye parusa.jpg|thumb|right|Shtandart playing a key role of Scarlet Sails [[Scarlet Sails (tradition)|holiday of alumnus]], 2007]] [[File:Gorch Fock und Shtandart vor dem Roten Schloss MSM (Flensburg-Mürwik August 2010 zur Nautics), Bild 02.jpg|thumb|right|The Shtandart with the [[Gorch Fock (1958)|Gorch Fock]] in front of the [[Naval Academy Mürwik]] (2010)]]
== Milestones of the ''Shtandart'' == * On September 4, 1999 the ''Shtandart'' was launched at the Petrovsky Shipyard in St Petersburg. * In June 2000 the ''Shtandart'' set sail on her maiden voyage. The frigate retraced the route taken by [[Peter I of Russia|Peter I]], during his [[Grand Embassy]]. * Since 2005, the ''Shtandart'' has played the part of the "dream ship" at the [[Scarlet Sails (tradition)|Scarlet Sails]] festival, an annual celebration of the end of the school year in [[Saint Petersburg|St. Petersburg]] from a novel by [[Alexander Grin]]<ref>[http://bearsandvodka.com/2010/01/more-days-to-celebrate/ Brief description of "Scarlet Sails" celebration and other holidays.]</ref><ref>[http://gov.spb.ru/culture/holiday/al_parusa another "Scarlet Sails" link (Russian).]</ref> *Over the last seventeen years (till end 2017) the ''Shtandart'' has sailed approximately {{convert|150000|nmi|km}} in the Baltic, North, Norwegian Barents and Mediterranean Seas, as well as sailing to [[Canary islands]]. She has visited one hundred and fifty ports in seventeen countries. Around 7000 trainees has been on board ''Shtandart'' for sailing adventure and training.
== Bureaucratic challenges == Beginning in 2007, all sailing vessels in Russia faced challenges with a certification. The new National Sea and River Authority (then Росморречнадзор/Rosmorrechnadzor, now Госморречнадзор/[[Gosmorrechnadzor]]) refused to issue certificates for sailing ships. The ''Shtandart'' was one of the most prominent of these vessels, so her dispute with this government agency was widely publicized.<ref name="Lenizdat">{{cite news|url=http://www.lenizdat.ru/a0/ru/pm1/c-1064238-0.html|trans-title=Vladimir Martus: the Reason for the conflict "Shtandart" vs Rosmorrechnadzor "- too great a contract sum |title=Владимир Мартусь: Причина конфликта ""Штандарт" vs Росморречнадзор" - слишком большая сумма контракта|last=Pirogovsky|first=Artem|date=2008-07-10|work=Mediaconflict|publisher=Lenizdat|language=Russian|accessdate=2009-09-12}}</ref> The Northwest directorate of the Rosmorrechnadzor cancelled the ''Shtandart's'' certifications but the St. Petersburg Arbitration Court reversed the decision in favor of the frigate, and the certificate's cancellation was ruled illegal.<ref>[http://www.cityspb.ru/goto/140693 ''Gazeta'' article about the case.]</ref> The ship has now been sailing around in Europe for the last ten years. It is not known when she could return to her home port.
== ''Shtandart's'' activities in 2000–2017 == * June 25, 2000 - the ''Shtandart'' has left St Petersburg port for her maiden voyage * Season 2000 route: St Petersburg — Vysby — [[Zaandam]] — Ijmuiden — Dunkirk — Roskoff — [[Brest, France|Brest]] for [[Brest 2000]] — London — Amsterdam — Bremerhaven [[Sail Bremerhaven]] — St Malo * Season 2001 route: St Malo — Amsterdam — Kalmar — St Petersburg — Aalesund [[Tall Ships' Races]] — Bergen — Esbjerg — Oudeschild — Brugge — Portsmouth * season 2002 route: Portsmouth — Harwich — Rotterdam — Den Helder — Hamburg — St Petersburg * season 2003 route: St Petersburg — Jakobstad — Sassnitz — Wilhelmshaven — Turku — Viborg — St Petersburg * season 2004 route: St Petersburg — Copenhagen — Stavern — Whisby — Hartlepool — Brest — Rotterdam — Antwerpen — Aalborg — Rostock — Helsingor — Lubeck — Frederikshavn — Karlskrona — Viborg — St Petersburg * season 2005 route: St Petersburg — Copenhagen — Odense — Halmstad — Helsinki — St Petersburg — Baltiisk— Lelystad — Rochester — London — Lowestoft — Hartlepool — Newcastle — Frederikstad (TSR) — Bremerhaven — Helgoland — Wismar — Travemunde — Frederikshavn — Gøteborg — Szczecin — Kotka — St Petersburg * season 2006 route: St Petersburg — Rotterdam — Travemunde — Kaliningrad — Karlskroona — Rostock — Frederickshavn — Lubeck — Kalmar — St Petersburg * season 2007 route: ST Petersburg — Hamburg — St Petersburg — TSR ports — St Petersburg * season 2008: St Petersburg * On August 25, 2009 the ''Shtandart'' sailed from St Petersburg all way around [[Norway|Norway's]] [[North Cape, Norway|North Cape]]. * During the winter of 2009–2010, the ship remained in [[Oslo]], Norway, for winter quarters. * The ''Shtandart'' took part in the Sail 2010 tall ships' festival in Bremerhaven, Germany between August 25 and 29. * The ''Shtandart'' took part in the Royal Greenwich Tall Ships Festival in London, UK between September 5 and 9. * season 2010 route: Norway — Poland — Germany — Finland — Belgium (TSR ports) — Denmark — Norway — Germany — Netherlands * Sason 2011 route: Lelystad — Hamburg — [[Hellevoetsluis]] — Fredericia — Rotterdam (Filming ''[[Nova Zembla (film)|Nova Zembla]]'') — Gdansk — Klaipeda (TSR Ports) — Turku — Great Yarmouth — Zaandam — Dordrecht — Hamburg * season 2012 route: Hamburg — Tallinn — Bremerhaven — Risor — Flensburg — Hellevoetsluis * season 2013 route: Amsterdam — Hamburg — Rouen — Kiel — Helsinki — Riga — Szczecin — Honfleur — St Malo — Bilbao — La Coruna — Lisbon — Portimao — Essueira — Las Palmas * season 2014 route: [[Santa-Cruz de Tenerife]] — [[Madeira]] — Cherbourg — Kampen — Hamburg — Szczecin — Helsingor — Hanko — Rostock — Gdynia — London — Luebeck * season 2015 route: Swanage — Hamburg — Riga — Klaipeda — Szczecin — [[Sandefjord]] — [[Aalesund]] — Kristiansand — Amsterdam (Sail Amsterdam 2015) — Lisbon — Malaga — Cannes — Rome — Genoa — Napoli — Palermo * season 2016 route: Barcelona — Malaga — Gibraltar — Cascais — Ferrol — Barcelona — Sete — Tarragona — Rochefort — Brest — Swanage — Edinbough —Blyth — Goteborg — Plymouth — St Malo — Bordeaux — Porto * season 2017 route: [[Vila do Conde]] — Cadis — Vigo — Vannes — Dublin — Belfast — Liverpool — Honfleur — Kotka — Turku — Klaipeda — Szczecin — Copenhagen — La Rochelle — Nantes — Copenhagen — St Malo — Barcelona
== ''Shtandart'' in films == * 2007 : ''[[The Sovereign's Servant]]'', a Russian [[war film]] written and directed by [[Oleg Ryaskov]]. * 2011 : ''[[The secret service agent's memories]]'', a Russian historical film and TV series based on the novel by [[Oleg Ryaskov]], who is also the director. * 2011 : ''[[Nova Zembla (film)|Nova Zembla]]'', a Dutch historical drama film directed by [[Reinout Oerlemans]]. * 2015 : ''[[Michiel de Ruyter (film)|Michiel de Ruyter]]'', a 2015 Dutch film about the [[Dutch Golden Age|17th-century]] admiral [[Michiel de Ruyter]] directed by [[Roel Reiné]]. On the English promotional website, the film has the title ''Admiral''<ref>[http://www.admiralthemovie.com/ Admiral]. Retrieved on 30 January 2015.</ref>.
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == {{Commons category|Shtandart (ship, 1999)}} * [http://www.shtandart.ru/ Official Shtandart website (Russian)] * [http://www.shtandart.com/ Official Shtandart website (English)] * [http://marinetraffic.com/ais/shipdetails.aspx?MMSI=273452840 Shtandart on the Marine Traffic AIS tracking service]
