{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox television | show_name_2 = | image = | caption = | genre = [[Astronomy]]
[[educational television|Educational]] | runtime = 3 minutes | starring = Tony Flanders | theme_music_composer = | theme = | country = United States | first_aired = {{start date|2011|10|19}} | last_aired = {{End date|2014|4|28}} | num_episodes = 52 episodes annually | website = http://www.skyandtelescope.com/videos/skyweek | language = English | network = [[PBS]] | picture_format = | num_seasons = 4 | location = | camera = [[Chroma key|Green screen]] }} '''''SkyWeek''''' was a weekly [[astronomy]] television program created by ''[[Sky & Telescope]]'' magazine. The show was hosted by Tony Flanders, associate editor of ''Sky & Telescope'' magazine. Each episode of the program was released in one, three, and five-minute formats; and, the show's content and format were similar to that of another weekly astronomy program called ''[[Star Gazers]]''. ''SkyWeek'' was carried by many [[PBS]] affiliates. == Content == ''SkyWeek'' was an [[Educational television|educational]] program that described [[Astronomical object|celestial]] events for the upcoming week. The show was aimed primarily at the general public and required no prior knowledge of astronomy. However, it also contained information that was likely to be interesting to experienced [[amateur astronomers]]. It depicted [[celestial objects]] in the night sky that could be seen without special equipment such as [[telescope]]s. Sky and Telescope's associate editor, Tony Flanders hosted the show, which was available in one-, three- and five-minute versions. == Production == ''SkyWeek'' was produced by New Track Media, which publishes ''Sky & Telescope'' magazine. The show was distributed to [[PBS]] stations through [[American Public Television]]. Images from the [[Hubble Space Telescope]] and many other professional and amateur sources were used in the production of the show. On April 16, 2014, Tony Flanders announced that the episode covering the week of April 28 to May 4, 2014 would be the last for the series. Flanders reported that the series was being discontinued because of insufficient money from sponsors required to cover the show's costs. == Episodes == Episodes were titled by the week of the events they describe. The production code used was of the form YYMMDD (2 digit year, 2 digit month, 2 digit day) for the date the episode was best suited to be broadcast. === Season 1: 2011 === The show premiered on November 19, 2011 with the inaugural episode covering the week of November 21 to 27 of 2011. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%; background:#FFFFFF" |- style="color:#FFFFFF" ! style="background:#B22222; width:4%"| Series # ! style="background:#B22222; width:4%"| Episode # ! style="background:#B22222"| Title ! style="background:#B22222; width:10%"| View Episode ! style="background:#B22222; width:18%"| Original air date ! style="background:#B22222; width:10%"| Production Code {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 1 | EpisodeNumber2 = 1 | Title = SkyWeek November 21–27, 2011 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0001_skyweek-november-21-27-2011/ view] | ProdCode = #111120 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2011|11|20}} | ShortSummary = Thanksgiving week is [[new Moon]] week, allowing what might be our last good view of the summer [[Milky Way]]. Also, let’s take a look at [[Venus]] and [[Jupiter]], the two brightest planets. | LineColor = 500650 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 2 | EpisodeNumber2 = 2 | Title = SkyWeek November 28 - December 4, 2011 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0002_skyweek-november-28-december-4-2011/ view] | ProdCode = #111127 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2011|11|27}} | ShortSummary = As the [[Moon]] waxes to half lit, let’s take a look at the brightest star in each section of the sky: [[Vega]] setting in the west, [[Fomalhaut]] cruising low over the southern horizon, and [[Capella (star)|Capella]] rising in the east. | LineColor = 500650 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 3 | EpisodeNumber2 = 3 | Title = SkyWeek December 5–11, 2011 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0003_skyweek-december-5-11-2011/ view] | ProdCode = #111204 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2011|12|04}} | ShortSummary = This week the Moon puts on the best sky show of the year for stargazers in the western U.S. — a total [[lunar eclipse]]. And we’ll look at [[Jupiter]], the king of the planets. | LineColor = 500650 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 4 | EpisodeNumber2 = 4 | Title = SkyWeek December 12–18, 2011 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0004skyweek-december-12-18-2011/ view] | ProdCode = #111211 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2011|12|11}} | ShortSummary = This week boasts one of the year’s best [[meteor shower]]s — though the nearly full Moon will interfere with viewing them. And we’ll look at a constellation that flies upside-down in the sky. | LineColor = 500650 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 5 | EpisodeNumber2 = 5 | Title = SkyWeek December 19–25, 2011 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0005_skyweek-december-19-25-2011/ view] | ProdCode = #111218 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2011|12|18}} | ShortSummary = Wednesday December 21st is the longest night of the year and the beginning of winter in the Northern Hemisphere. Leading the pack of winter constellations is [[Taurus (constellation)|Taurus]], the Bull. | LineColor = 500650 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 6 | EpisodeNumber2 = 6 | Title = SkyWeek December 26 - January 1, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0006_skyweek-december-26-2011-january-1-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #111225 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2011|12|25}} | ShortSummary = [[Orion (constellation)|Orion]], the Hunter, may be the most amazing constellation in the sky. And [[Betelgeuse]], the star marking Orion’s left shoulder, is a red supergiant that’s ripe to explode as a supernova. | LineColor = 500650 }} |} === Season 2: 2012 === The 2012 season started on view] | ProdCode = #120101 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|01|01}} | ShortSummary = Weather permitting, North Americans can enjoy a little-known but unusually strong [[meteor shower]] before star, is on great display during January evenings. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 9 | EpisodeNumber2 = 3 | Title = SkyWeek January 16–22, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0009_skyweek-january-16-22-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120115 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|01|15}} | ShortSummary = The constellations [[Perseus (constellation)|Perseus]], [[Cassiopeia (constellation)|Cassiopeia]], and [[Andromeda (constellation)|Andromeda]] are linked together in the sky, and in Greek mythology. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 10 | EpisodeNumber2 = 4 | Title = SkyWeek January 23–29, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0010_skyweek-january-23-29-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120122 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|01|22}} | ShortSummary = Learn how [[Perseus]] rescued [[Andromeda (mythology)|Andromeda]], and find out how and why Queen Cassiopeia is doomed to rotate forever in the sky. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 11 | EpisodeNumber2 = 5 | Title = SkyWeek January 30 - February 5, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0011_skyweek-january-30-february-5-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120129 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|01|29}} | ShortSummary = This week [[Eros]], the grandaddy of all near-Earth asteroids, is making its closest approach to Earth since 1975, just 16.6 million miles away. That make it our second-closest neighbor after the [[Moon]]. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 12 | EpisodeNumber2 = 6 | Title = SkyWeek February 6–12, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0012_skyweek-february-6-12-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120205 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|02|05}} | ShortSummary = [[Mars]], the Red Planet, is beginning to appear in the evening sky. In many ways, Mars is the planet most like Earth, with deserts, dust storms, and maybe even running water on rare occasions. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 13 | EpisodeNumber2 = 7 | Title = SkyWeek February 13–19, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0013_skyweek-february-13-19-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120212 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|02|12}} | ShortSummary = [[Orion (constellation)|Orion]] is center stage in the south as the sky grows dark. This constellation contains 7 of the sky’s 100 brightest stars. And most of Orion’s main stars are physically related. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 14 | EpisodeNumber2 = 8 | Title = SkyWeek February 20–26, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0014_skyweek-february-20-26-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120219 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|02|19}} | ShortSummary = The waxing crescent [[Moon]] passes close to three planets this week: [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]], [[Venus]], and [[Jupiter]]. All of them travel along a path in the sky called the zodiac. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 15 | EpisodeNumber2 = 9 | Title = SkyWeek February 27 - March 4, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0015_skyweek-febraury-27-march-4-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120226 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|02|26}} | ShortSummary = This week the night sky’s six or seven brightest objects are all visible 45 minutes after sunset, something that won’t happen again for decades. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 16 | EpisodeNumber2 = 10 | Title = SkyWeek March 5–11, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0016_skyweek-march-5-11-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120304 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|03|04}} | ShortSummary = This is a dramatic week for planet watchers. In the east, [[Mars]] is at its brightest and closest to Earth for 2012. On the opposite side of the sky, [[Venus]] and [[Jupiter]] form a spectacular pair. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 17 | EpisodeNumber2 = 11 | Title = SkyWeek March 12–18, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0017_skyweek-march-12-18-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120311 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|03|11}} | ShortSummary = [[Venus]] and [[Jupiter]] are paired spectacularly in the western sky. Meanwhile, the twin stars [[Castor (star)|Castor]] and [[Pollux (star)|Pollux]] form a less glamorous but much longer lived pair high in the south. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 18 | EpisodeNumber2 = 12 | Title = SkyWeek March 19–25, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0018_skyweek-march-19-25-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120318 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|03|18}} | ShortSummary = [[Spring (season)|Spring]] starts this week on Monday night, a date called the [[Vernal Equinox]]. For the next six months, days will be longer than nights in the Northern Hemisphere. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 19 | EpisodeNumber2 = 13 | Title = SkyWeek March 26 - April 1, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0019_skyweek-march-26-april-1-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120325 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|03|25}} | ShortSummary = The [[Big Dipper]], the best-known star pattern in the sky is now high in the northeast in the evening. It’s just part of the much larger constellation [[Ursa Major]]. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 20 | EpisodeNumber2 = 14 | Title = SkyWeek April 2–8, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0020_skyweek-april-2-8-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120401 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|04|01}} | ShortSummary = [[Venus]] passes through the [[Pleiades]] star cluster on Monday and Tuesday. And [[Saturn]], the magnificent ringed planet, is now well up in the evening sky. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 21 | EpisodeNumber2 = 15 | Title = SkyWeek April 9–15, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0021_skyweek-april-9-15-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120408 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|04|08}} | ShortSummary = You can see five great star clusters with your unaided eyes on evenings at this time of year. One of them is widely known, but rarely recognized as a true star cluster. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 22 | EpisodeNumber2 = 16 | Title = SkyWeek April 16–22, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0022_skyweek-april-16-22-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120415 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|04|15}} | ShortSummary = [[Corona Borealis]], the Northern Crown, is a compact jewel of a constellation. And the dazzling orange star [[Arcturus]] nearby may be a visitor from another galaxy. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 23 | EpisodeNumber2 = 17 | Title = SkyWeek April 23–29, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0023_skyweek-april-23-29-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120422 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|04|22}} | ShortSummary = The waxing crescent [[Moon]] appears higher in the west each evening this week. And the planet [[Venus]] is also now a crescent, a phenomenon of great historical importance. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 24 | EpisodeNumber2 = 18 | Title = SkyWeek April 30 - May 6, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0024_skyweek-april-30-may-6-2012-2/ view] | ProdCode = #120429 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|04|29}} | ShortSummary = The closest and biggest full [[Moon]] of 2012 happens on Saturday, May 5th. That means that high tides will be unusually high and low tides will be unusually low. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 25 | EpisodeNumber2 = 19 | Title = SkyWeek May 7–13, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0025_skyweek-may-7-13-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120506 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|05|06}} | ShortSummary = [[Venus]], [[Mars]], and [[Saturn]] are all paired with bright stars this week. Saturn is in [[Virgo (astrology)|Virgo]], the great constellation of spring, and the site of a remarkable galaxy cluster. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 26 | EpisodeNumber2 = 20 | Title = SkyWeek May 14–20, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0026_skyweek-may-14-20-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120513 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|05|13}} | ShortSummary = A partial [[solar eclipse]] is visible over most of the U.S. on Sunday, May 20th. And in parts of the West the eclipse is annular, with a ring of sunlight all around the Moon’s dark disk. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 27 | EpisodeNumber2 = 21 | Title = SkyWeek May 21–27, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0027_skyweek-may-21-27-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120520 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|05|20}} | ShortSummary = This week is your last easy chance to see Venus before it crosses the Sun’s disk on June 5th. And the constellation [[Hercules (constellation)|Hercules]], with its magnificent star cluster, is rising in the east. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 28 | EpisodeNumber2 = 22 | Title = SkyWeek May 28 - June 3, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0028_skyweek-may-28-june-3-2012/ view] | ProdCode = #120527 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|05|27}} | ShortSummary = Get ready for the partial [[lunar eclipse]] before dawn on June 4th and the twice-in-a-lifetime chance to see [[Venus]]’s dark disk cross the Sun on June 5th. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 29 | EpisodeNumber2 = 23 | Title = SkyWeek June 4–10, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0029_skyweek-june-4-10-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|06|03}} | ShortSummary = The Moon experiences a partial [[lunar eclipse]] before dawn on Monday. And we look at the historical and scientific importance of Tuesday’s [[Transit of Venus]] across the Sun. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 30 | EpisodeNumber2 = 24 | Title = SkyWeek June 11–17, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0030_skyweek-june-11-17-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|06|10}} | ShortSummary = The huge intertwined constellations [[Ophiuchus]] and [[Serpens]] fill much of the southeastern sky. Ophiuchus is sometimes called the thirteenth constellation of the zodiac. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 31 | EpisodeNumber2 = 25 | Title = SkyWeek June 18–24, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0031_skyweek-june-18-24-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|06|17}} | ShortSummary = [[Summer (season)|Summer]] officially begins on Wednesday this week. In addition to having the longest days, this time of year has the most luxurious sunrises, sunsets, and twilights. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 32 | EpisodeNumber2 = 26 | Title = SkyWeek June 25 - July 1, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0032_skyweek-june-25-july-1-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|06|24}} | ShortSummary = The waxing [[Moon]] passes [[Mars]], [[Spica]], and [[Saturn]] this week. Saturn possesses an extraordinary retinue of moons, including the amazingly Earth-like moon [[Titan (moon)|Titan]]. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 33 | EpisodeNumber2 = 27 | Title = SkyWeek July 2–8, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0033_skyweek-july-2-8-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|07|01}} | ShortSummary = [[Vega]], [[Altair]], and [[Deneb]], the three bright high-flying stars of summer, are now well up in the east. Together, they form a huge shape called the Summer Triangle. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 34 | EpisodeNumber2 = 28 | Title = SkyWeek July 9–15, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0034_skyweek-july-9-15-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|07|08}} | ShortSummary = Magnificent [[Scorpius]], the Scorpion, is at its highest around 10 or 11 pm. Its brightest star is dazzling reddish Antares, meaning "rival of Mars." | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 35 | EpisodeNumber2 = 29 | Title = SkyWeek July 16–22, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0035_skyweek-july-16-22-2012-2/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|07|15}} | ShortSummary = Summer evenings are when the [[Milky Way]]’s brightest part is visible. Unfortunately, the Milky Way is easily overwhelmed by poorly designed artificial lights. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 36 | EpisodeNumber2 = 30 | Title = SkyWeek July 23–29, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0036_skyweek-july-23-29-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|07|22}} | ShortSummary = [[Vega]] and [[Altair]], the brightest stars of the Summer Triangle, are linked in legends worldwide. And their names tell a fascinating story. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 37 | EpisodeNumber2 = 31 | Title = SkyWeek July 30 - August 5, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0037_skyweek-july-30-august-5-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|07|29}} | ShortSummary = [[Mars]] approaches [[Saturn]] and [[Spica]] dramatically this week at dusk. And the Day Star, our own Sun, is a never-ending source of astronomical wonder. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 38 | EpisodeNumber2 = 32 | Title = SkyWeek August 6–12, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0038_skyweek-august-6-12-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|08|05}} | ShortSummary = [[Mars]], [[Saturn]], and [[Spica]] form a triangle low in the southwest. And the [[Perseid meteor shower]] will be at its best late on Saturday night. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 39 | EpisodeNumber2 = 33 | Title = SkyWeek August 13–19, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0039_skyweek-august-13-19-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|08|12}} | ShortSummary = [[Mars]] threads the narrow gap between [[Saturn]] and [[Spica]]. And later in the evening we can look deep into the heart of the Sagittarius Milky Way. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 40 | EpisodeNumber2 = 34 | Title = SkyWeek August 20–26, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0040_skyweek-august-20-26-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|08|19}} | ShortSummary = Between and below [[Cygnus (constellation)|Cygnus]] the Dolphin and [[Aquila (constellation)|Aquila]] the Eagle lie two tiny but very attractive constellations: [[Delphinus]] the Dolphin and [[Sagitta]] the Arrow. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 41 | EpisodeNumber2 = 35 | Title = SkyWeek August 27 - September 2, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0041_skyweek-august-27-september-2-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|08|26}} | ShortSummary = Our [[Moon]] is more than one-quarter the diameter of Earth. The only comparable pair in the solar system is [[Pluto]] and its moon Charon. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 42 | EpisodeNumber2 = 36 | Title = SkyWeek September 3–9, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0042_september-3-9-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|09|02}} | ShortSummary = The small but shapely constellation [[Lyra]] is chock-full of celestial wonders. In Greek mythology this Lyre belonged to the great musician [[Orpheus]]. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 43 | EpisodeNumber2 = 37 | Title = SkyWeek September 10–16, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0043_skyweek-september-10-16-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|09|09}} | ShortSummary = [[Cygnus (constellation)|Cygnus]] the Swan flies high overhead. The Great Rift that splits the Milky Way in two starts near the heart of Cygnus. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 44 | EpisodeNumber2 = 38 | Title = SkyWeek September 17–23, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0044_skyweek-september-17-23-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|09|16}} | ShortSummary = The planet [[Uranus]] is extraordinarily close to a similarly bright star. Uranus was discovered in 1781 by an amateur astronomer named [[William Herschel]]. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 45 | EpisodeNumber2 = 39 | Title = SkyWeek September 24–30, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0045_skyweek-september-24-30-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|09|23}} | ShortSummary = The elegant but little-known constellation [[Draco (constellation)|Draco]] the Dragon lies coiled around the [[Little Dipper]], with its head high in the sky. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 46 | EpisodeNumber2 = 40 | Title = SkyWeek October 1–7, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0046_skyweek-october-1-7-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|09|30}} | ShortSummary = The constellations of the Great Sea spill from the jug of [[Aquarius (astrology)|Aquarius]], the Water Carrier. And [[Neptune]], the outermost planet, is in Aquarius now. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 47 | EpisodeNumber2 = 41 | Title = SkyWeek October 8–14, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0047_skyweek-october-8-14-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|10|07}} | ShortSummary = [[Cassiopeia (constellation)|Cassiopeia]] and [[Perseus]] are the prime constellations of the autumn Milky Way. And they’re home to some of the sky’s finest star clusters. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 48 | EpisodeNumber2 = 42 | Title = SkyWeek October 15–21, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0148_skyweek-october-15-21-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|10|14}} | ShortSummary = The constellations [[Andromeda (constellation)|Andromeda]], [[Cassiopeia (constellation)|Cassiopeia]], [[Cepheus (constellation)|Cepheus]], and [[Perseus]] are linked in Greek mythology by a wonderful story. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 49 | EpisodeNumber2 = 43 | Title = SkyWeek October 22–28, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0149_skyweek-october-22-28-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|10|21}} | ShortSummary = The [[Moon]], our closest neighbor in space, is amazing to the unaided eye and binoculars. Its surface reveals a lot about Earth’s history, too. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 50 | EpisodeNumber2 = 44 | Title = SkyWeek October 29 - November 4, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0150_skyweek-october-29-november-4-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|10|28}} | ShortSummary = [[Jupiter]]’s four biggest moons are whole worlds in their own right. They include the most active volcanoes known and a suspected habitat for life. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 51 | EpisodeNumber2 = 45 | Title = SkyWeek November 5–11, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0151_skyweek-november-5-11-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|11|04}} | ShortSummary = The [[Andromeda Galaxy]] is on fine display these evenings. It’s the most distant object you’re likely to see without binoculars or a telescope, but it’s right next door in cosmic terms. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 52 | EpisodeNumber2 = 46 | Title = SkyWeek November 12–18, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0152_skyweek-november-12-18-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|11|11}} | ShortSummary = A superthin [[Moon]] floats below [[Venus]] before sunrise on Monday, November 12th. And you might be able to spot the reborn crescent on Wednesday or Thursday evening. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 53 | EpisodeNumber2 = 47 | Title = SkyWeek November 19–25, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0153_skyweek-november-19-25-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|11|18}} | ShortSummary = Dazzling [[Jupiter]] blazes near the sky’s two most spectacular star clusters — the [[Pleiades]], or Seven Sisters, and the [[Hyades (star cluster)|Hyades]], the closest rich star cluster to Earth. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 54 | EpisodeNumber2 = 48 | Title = SkyWeek November 26 - December 2, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0154_skyweek-november-26-december-2-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|11|25}} | ShortSummary = [[Saturn]] glows very close to brilliant [[Venus]] before sunrise on Monday, November 26th. And the [[Moon]] is spectacularly close to bright [[Jupiter]] on Wednesday evening. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 55 | EpisodeNumber2 = 49 | Title = SkyWeek December 3–9, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0155_skyweek-december-3-9-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|12|02}} | ShortSummary = Three of the sky’s finest star formations are climbing the southeastern sky. The [[Pleaides]] lead the way, then [[Jupiter]] with the [[Hyades (star cluster)|Hyades]], and magnificent [[Orion (constellation)|Orion]] rounds out the group. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 56 | EpisodeNumber2 = 50 | Title = SkyWeek December 10–16, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0156_skyweek-december-10-16-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|12|09}} | ShortSummary = The [[Geminid]] meteor shower will be strongest from Thursday evening through Friday morning, though more meteors than usual will fall all week. Conditions are perfect this year, with no Moon to blind you to the faintest meteors. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 57 | EpisodeNumber2 = 51 | Title = SkyWeek December 17–23, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0157_skyweek-december-17-23-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|12|16}} | ShortSummary = [[Winter (season)|Winter]] starts on Friday, and coincidentally the ancient [[Mayan calendar]] flips over to a new "baktun." Contrary to the doomsayers, nothing unusual will happen. But some astronomical phenomena are genuinely dangerous. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 58 | EpisodeNumber2 = 52 | Title = SkyWeek December 24–30, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0158_skyweek-december-24-30-2012/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|12|23}} | ShortSummary = The [[Moon]] pairs spectacularly with [[Jupiter]] on the evening of Christmas Day, December 25th. And [[Sirius]], the night sky’s brightest star, is at its highest at midnight as the year winds to its end. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 59 | EpisodeNumber2 = 53 | Title = SkyWeek December 31 - January 6, 2012 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0159_skyweek-december-31-2012-january-6-2013/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2012|12|30}} | ShortSummary = A splendid vista of bright stars and one dazzling planet greets stargazers on the stroke of the New Year. And two remarkable stars that vary in brightness are high in the northwest. | LineColor = 503806 }} |} === Season 3: 2013 === The 2013 season started on January 1, 2013. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%; background:#FFFFFF" |- style="color:#FFFFFF" ! style="background:#28837C; width:4%"| Series # ! style="background:#28837C; width:4%"| Episode # ! style="background:#28837C"| Title ! style="background:#28837C; width:10%"| View Episode ! style="background:#28837C; width:18%"| Original air date ! style="background:#28837C; width:10%"| Production Code {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 60 | EpisodeNumber2 = 1 | Title = SkyWeek January 7–13, 2013 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0160_skyweekjanuary-7-13-2013/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2013|01|06}} | ShortSummary = [[Auriga (constellation)|Auriga]] the Charioteer is nearly overhead in the evening sky. Its prominent pentagon includes dazzling [[Capella (star)|Capella]], meaning She Goat, the sixth brightest star in the night sky. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 61 | EpisodeNumber2 = 2 | Title = SkyWeek January 14–20, 2013 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0161_january-14-20-2013/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2013|01|13}} | ShortSummary = This is a great week to observe the [[Moon]], our closest neighbor in space. Spot the two smallest planets side by side in the sky — but nowhere near each other in space. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 65 | EpisodeNumber2 = 6 | Title = SkyWeek February 11–17, 2013 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0165_february-11-17-2013/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2013|02|10}} | ShortSummary = A beautifully thin crescent [[Moon]] floats upper right of [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]] on Monday. This is a great week to spot Mercury, something few people have knowingly done. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 66 | EpisodeNumber2 = 7 | Title = SkyWeek February 18–24, 2013 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0166_february-18-24-2013/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2013|02|17}} | ShortSummary = The constellation [[Gemini (constellation)|Gemini]], the Twins, flies almost overhead in late February and early March. It looks like a cloud of light to the unaided eye, but binoculars show that it’s a glorious star cluster. | LineColor = 503806 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 69 | EpisodeNumber2 = 10 | Title = SkyWeek March 11–17, 2013 | Aux2 = [http://www.skyandtelescope.tv/videos/0117_march-11-17-2013/ view] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2013|03|10}} | ShortSummary = If we’re lucky, [[Comet PANSTARRS]] will shine low in the west shortly after sunset this week. {{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox school | name = Subway Academy I | image = | caption = | address = 16 Phin Avenue | city = [[Toronto]] | province = [[Ontario]] | postcode = [[Postal codes in Canada|M4J 3T2]] | country = Canada | schooltype = [[High school#Canada|High school]] | schoolboard = [[Toronto District School Board]] | superintendent = Jill Worthy | trustee = Cathy Dandy | principal = Michael Ferguson | grades_label = [[Education in Canada#Levels in education|Grades]] | grades = 9-12 | schedule_type = Semestered | enrollment = 124 | language = [[Canadian English|English]] }} '''Subway Academy I''' is a [[Public school (government funded)|public]] [[alternative school|alternative]] [[high school]] in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]]. Originally, Subway Academy I was simply called "Subway Academy", but after Subway Academy II opened, the name was changed to "Subway Academy I". It was founded in September 1973, making it one of the oldest secondary alternative schools in Toronto. The original staff were Achim Krull, Judith Robertson and Murray Shukyn. The school was a reflection of the Ivan Illich<ref>http://www.preservenet.com/theory/Illich/Deschooling/intro.html</ref> "deschooling" movement, which proposed that people would learn best from community resources. As a result, a directory of resources along the Toronton subway system was created, and the school derives its name from that initiative. The community resource aspect of the program however faded very quickly. Students were more interested in formal credit courses and academic courses leading to admission to university or college admission. Subway Academy started as an independent studies program. It was intended to make education available to students with family or other obligations which limited their ability to attend school during regular hours and who could not attend night school. The school enrolled students at any time during the year, not just in September. Originally, there was no upper age limit on enrolment. The school attracted many adults. The independent studies program at Subway Academy operated very differently from regular high school programs. Students met their teachers by appointment several times a week, but there were no formal classes. During the appointments, students reviewed their progress with their teachers, wrote tests, handed in assignments, and received new work. Students could work at the school, or at home, or at the local library, wherever they were comfortable. Students started courses when they joined, and finished courses whenever they had completed all the required work. Additional courses could be started at any time. Today Subway Academy combined formal classes with independent studies, and students are required to complete courses during a regular semestered timeframe. Subway Academy One continues to share a building with [[Eastern Commerce Collegiate Institute]]. Today it offers courses from grades 9 to 12 at both the academic and applied level. As the enrolment at Subway Academy increased, it was divided into two branches. Subway Academy II was opened in the west end of Toronto. Judith Robertson became the first coordinator of that program. It continues today as an independent studies program.

{{multiple issues| {{advert|date=August 2016}} {{lead too short|date=August 2016}} {{overly detailed|date=August 2016}} {{Orphan|date=September 2018}} }} {{Infobox school | image= Logo_for_the_article_sun_rise.png | caption = Sun Rise English School | image_size = | name= Sun Rise English School | motto = Education for Development | principal = Mr.Tek Bhadaur Shrestha | type = [[private school|Private]] | established = 1987 | staff = 109 | faculty = 120 | students = 2000 [[Approximation|approx]] | endowment = [[Nepalese Rupees]] 29 [[10000000 (number)|million]] | city = [[Bharatpur, Nepal|Bharatpur]] | state = [[Narayani Zone|Narayani]] | country = [[Nepal]] | district = Chitwan | free_label = Newspaper | free = [[Sun-Rise Souvenir]] | nickname = SRES | affiliations = [[SLC Board Nepal]] | authorizer = [http://www.moe.gov.np/ Ministry of Education, Nepal] | information = Tel +977 56 522566/524566/525266 | website = {{url|sres.edu.np}} |colors = [[Red]] {{color box|red}} [[Blue]] {{color box|blue}} [[Yellow]] {{color box|yellow}}
}}
'''Sun Rise English School<ref>https://www.facebook.com/sresbharatpur/</ref>''' is a private school in [[Bharatpur, Nepal|Bharatpur]], [[Chitwan District|Chitwan]]. It is one of the premier private schools of [[Nepal]].<ref>{{cite web| url = http://sres.edu.np/?page_id=130 | title = Sun Rise English School | publisher = SRES}}</ref>
==History== Sun Rise English School was established in 1987 by Mr. Dinanath Duwadi, in his own home in Bharatpur-06, Krishnapur, Chitwan. Classes ran from Nursery to 5th grade. There were 33 students enrolled and 5 staff and teachers working in the school. After running the school for 3 years in his home, the board of directors moved it to Dipendra Nagar. The school was moved behind Birendra Multiple Campus, Dipendra Nagar in the fall of 1992. After running the school for two more years, the school's Board of Directors declared liquidity. In the summer of 1994, the school was closed with 142 students enrolled and studying.
Within a week, the school was purchased by a group of young educators. The new group registered the school as '''Sun Rise English School''', removing the word 'boarding' from its previous name. Mr. Bal Bahadur Acharya was selected as the acting principal of the school. The new management brought all the teachers and staff, and all the physical assets including the school building from the previous management and started the classes at the same place behind Birendra Multiple Campus in Dipendra Nagar.
The school has attended generally good reputation as one of the best Secondary Schools outside Kathmandu Valley. With overall excellent results in the [[School Leaving Certificate (Nepal)|SLC]] examinations, the school has established itself as a strong competitor in the Nepalese education system. [[File:Sun Rise English School Administration.jpg|thumb|right|A scenic view of the old school building school Library]]
==Administration== The new management took over in 1994. The school used to be administered completely by the Board of Directors elected by the Trustees of school till 2006. With a demand for a parent representative on the school's Board of Directors, the previous system was finally removed. Directors will be composed like this: * From Share Holders-1 representative * From Parents-2 representatives(1 Male/ 1 Female) * From Teachers-1 representative * From Local Educationalists-1 representative * From Government of Nepal, School Invigilators-1 representative * Principal [[File:Sun_Rise_English_School.jpg|thumb|Left|Inside View]]
==Course of study== The school operates two courses of study: * School Leaving Certificate level (a nationwide curriculum up to class 10 prescribed by the [[Department of Education (Nepal)|Department of Education]], Ministry of Education and Sports, Government of Nepal
Most students go on to attend high schools in [[Chitwan]], [[Kathmandu]], [[Pokhara]] and to some [[Education in India|Indian]] cities. Sun Rise has been producing excellent results in [[School Leaving Certificate|SLC]] examinations for the past 14 years. Every year till now, the school has been amongst the top three schools in the district with the best results.
==+2 Science,Management And Humanities== First +2 Batch batch have been started. [[File:Sunriseschool.jpg|thumb|right|+2 Classes Started from 2074 B.S.]] [[File:This_is_the_design_of_+2_Building.jpg|thumb|left|+2 Building]]
==SLC Results== {| Class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year !! Distinction !! First Division !! Second Division !! Third Division !! Pass only |- | 1997 ||10||18| 3 || -|| 1 |- | 1998 || 4|| 17|| 1|| -|| 1 |- | 1999 || 8|| 21|| 5|| -|| - |- | 2000 || 4|| 31|| 7 || -|| - |- | 2001 || 4|| 56|| 8|| -|| 2 |- | 2002 || 12|| 67|| 8|| -|| 4 |- | 2003 || 9|| 87|| 24|| -|| 8 |- | 2004 || 5|| 89|| 35|| -|| 2 |- | 2005 || 6|| 97|| 22|| -|| 3 |- | 2006 || 16|| 104|| 4 || -|| 1 |- | 2007 || 52|| 78|| 3|| -|| -|- |- | 2008 || 72|| 76|| 1|| -|| -|- |- | 2009 || 47|| 111|| 7|| -|| -|1 |- | 2010 || 114|| 58|| 1|| -|| -|- |- | 2011 || 43|| 106|| 7|| -|| -|- |- | 2012 || 61|| 101|| 14|| -|| -|- |- | 2013 || 66|| 102|| 2|| -|| -|- |- |2014 || 67|| -|| || -|| -|-

==SLC Results 2072 (Grading System)== {| Class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year !! A+ !! A !! B+ !! B !! C+ !! C !! D+ !! D !! E |- | 2015 || 44 || 55|| 42 || 28 || 8 || 2 || 0 || 0 || 0 |-
|}
{{coord missing|Nepal}}
==Features== Computer Education:
SRES possesses two computer laboratories equipped with set of 46 computers. This subject has been introduced as a part of curriculum from class VI onwards.
Library:
SRES has two separate libraries for its senior and junior students. A wide variety of books are kept to encourage the students to develop an interest in different subjects. These libraries are equipped with all kinds of audio/visual materials, children's films etc.
Science Laboratory:
A well-equipped science laboratory has been set up with the number of equipments and chemicals necessary for secondary course.
Transportation:
The school has four buses to pick up the children and drop them. Special subsidy has been provided to moderate the service post.
Health Service:
SRES has been providing first aid service. Besides, the school manages every possible types of Health service programme available. An infirmary with a nurse has been set up to provide better service to its children.
Scholarship:
SRES has special provisions to provide help to the intelligent and hard-working students as well as under privileged students. The school offers S.L.C. merit scholarships to the national and district toppers from the school.
Hostel:
SRES has two separate hostels for both Boys and Girls. The hostels provide highly safe environment under the direct supervision of the managing body. A great attention has been paid to ensure the comfort, cleanliness and hygiene of the children. Special class hours are arranged to help the weaker students.
Canteen:
Day scholars can have Tiffin at school canteen located inside school premise. A vigilant eye has been kept to ensure the hygiene and cost of the food available.
==Awards== Pasang Lahmu Award
Galaxy Trophy
Best NJRC in the district 2058,2059
Best School in the district, 2064
Best School in the district,2065
Best School in the district,2066

{{use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox Chinese-language singer and actor | name = Teresa Carpio | image = | caption = | chinesename = | tradchinesename = 杜麗莎 | simpchinesename = 杜丽莎 | pinyinchinesename = Dù Lìshā | jyutpingchinesename = Dou6 Lai6 Saa1 | birth_name = | ancestry = [[Hong Kong]], [[Shanghai]], [[Philippines]] | origin = {{HKG}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1956|9|30|df=yes}} | birth_place = {{flagicon|British Hong Kong}} [[British Hong Kong|Hong Kong]] | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | restingplacecoordinates = | othername = | occupation = [[Singer]], [[actress]] | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Cantopop]] | instrument = [[Singing|Vocal]]s, [[piano]] | voicetype = | label = | yearsactive = 1975–present | currentmembers = | pastmembers = | associatedact = | spouse = | partner = [[Peter Mui|Peter Ken Mui]]
[[Andreas Panayi]] | children = [[T.V. Carpio]]
Alexias Panayi
Serena Panayi | parents = [[Fernando Carpio]] (1932-present) | awards='''[[RTHK Top Ten Chinese Gold Songs Awards|Golden Needle Awards]]'''
2007 Lifetime Achievement }}'''Teresa Carpio''' (born 30 September 1956 in Hong Kong) is a [[Hong Kong English pop]] and [[Cantopop singer]],{{cite web |title=George Lam is the real deal |author=Seto Kit Yan |url=http://www.star-ecentral.com/news/story.asp?file=/2009/4/28/soundnstage/3781215&sec=soundnstage |date=2009-04-28 |publisher=The Star Online: Malaysia News |accessdate=2009-04-28}} [[actress]],{{cite web |title=Teresa Carpio |author=Ross Chen |url=http://www.lovehkfilm.com/people/carpio_teresa.htm |publisher=Love HK Film.com |accessdate=2009-04-28}} and singing teacher. As a singer she who has enjoyed substantial popularity in Hong Kong and other countries, particularly during the 1970s and 1980s. She is also the mother of singer [[T.V. Carpio]].{{cite web |title=Teresa and TV Carpio discuss Broadway's Spider-man Turn Off The Dark |author=David Gordon |url=http://www.theatermania.com/broadway/news/06-2011/news-flash-teresa-and-tv-carpio-discuss-broadways_38222.html |publisher=Theater Mania}} She is most well known for her Cantonese hits, 假如 (If), 仍然記得嗰一次 (I Still Remember That Time), 眉頭不再皺 (Sukiyaki), 何必放棄 (Why Give Up) and 真愛 (True Love). ==Family background== Carpio's father is [[Filipino people|Filipino]] and her mother [[Chinese people|Shanghainese]]. Born into a musical family (her grandfather was a concert [[violin]]ist and [[jazz guitarist]], her father Fernando, a [[jazz drummer]], and several uncles were also professional musicians), She began singing at age 6 when she entered and won Hong Kong's first Amateur Talent Quest. She is the eldest of five, all of whom have at some time been active in the music business. Her eldest daughter, [[T.V. Carpio|TV Carpio]], is a musician, actress and Broadway singer. ==Career== Carpio began her career as a [[child singer|child star]], winning Hong Kong's first Amateur Talent Quest in 1963 at the age of 6.{{Cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/article/648962/teresa-carpio|title=Teresa Carpio|newspaper=South China Morning Post|access-date=2017-02-11|language=en}} At age 11, she turned down a scholarship at [[St. Paul's Convent School|St Paul's Convent]] to work in her first job in Tahiti where her father was also working.{{Cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/article/235872/stepping-back-lions-den|title=Stepping back into the lion's den|newspaper=South China Morning Post|access-date=2017-02-11|language=en}} Following that, she worked in clubs until she went to Japan for a year where she met [[Shintaro Katsu]] who sponsored her during her time there. She released her first single in Japan in 1971, entitled Ainoko Mary (混血児マリー).{{Cite web|url=https://dreamwaterchildren.net/2012/02/05/vintage-japanese-movie%e3%80%80%e6%b7%b7%e8%a1%80%e5%85%90%e3%83%9e%e3%83%aa%e3%83%bc/|title=Music Video: Vintage Japanese Movie Song: Mongrel Marie 混血児マリー|date=2012-02-05|website=Dream of the Water Children: The Black Pacific|access-date=2017-02-11}}{{Citation|last=reftandlight3|title=Teresa Carpio - My First Love 1971|date=2014-12-04|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1scuqmn4JVg|accessdate=2017-02-11}} Returning to Hong Kong, she worked in many nightclubs, such as Danshaku, Gessekai and the Hyatt Hotel's Chin Chin Bar, until EMI came and offered her a recording deal. For several years from 1975 onwards Carpio had her own TV variety show in [[Hong Kong]], on which she performed both solo and with several of her siblings. She released many albums in Hong Kong from 1976 onwards; six of her albums under EMI went gold, in which she featured cover versions in English of western hits, including an album with [[George Lam]]. She made numerous television appearances in Hong Kong, in the late 1970s. Carpio was the first and the youngest Hong Kong singer ever to appear on national TV in Japan. She has performed in many other countries as far apart as [[Singapore]], [[Malaysia]], [[Tahiti]], Australia, Japan, Thailand, [[Brunei]], the United States and Canada. With the growing popularity of [[Cantopop]], Carpio started to record in [[Cantonese]] along with English, remaining popular despite increasing competition from newer stars, notably [[Anita Mui]]. Carpio broadened her career into acting with appearances in a number of films,{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0139568/|title=''Carpio's Starring Record IMDB Database''|publisher=imdb.com|accessdate=2010-12-02}} and auditioned for the lead role in [[Miss Saigon]], though this eventually went to [[Lea Salonga]]. She was no stranger to live musical theatre, having taken the lead role in the 1979 [[San Jose, California]] production of the stage musical ''[[City of Broken Promises]]'', based on the book by [[Austin Coates]], a story set in [[Macau]] which won Best Original Musical. Following her second marriage, Carpio moved to Canada and focused her attention on bringing up her family (she has three daughters; the eldest, [[T. V. Carpio]], by her first marriage, also an actor, singer and [[songwriter]]). == Discography == Carpio has released 25 albums to date, including 6 live recordings. Her first album, Teresa Carpio, was released in 1975 and then quickly followed up with five more solo albums from EMI as well as a duets album with George Lam. In 1981 she moved to WEA and released one Cantonese album. In 1983 she formed her own record company, TV Records, which released three more Cantonese albums, on which - together with her WEA album - are some of her most popular songs. Since then she has released several live CDs and DVDs as well as a few studio recordings. === English === {| class="wikitable" !Year !Title !Record Company |- |1975 |Teresa Carpio |EMI |- |1976 |Songs For You |EMI |- |1976 |You've Got Me For Company |EMI |- |1977 |Greatest Hits +2 |EMI |- |1977 |Teresa Carpio |EMI |- |1979 |Teresa Carpio |EMI |- |1986 |Tokyo Dreaming |Warner-Pioneer |- |1990 |If I Ever Needed Love |EMI |- |2006 |A Family Christmas Album |Teresa Carpio International |- |2009 |Hello |Teresa Carpio International |} === Cantonese === {| class="wikitable" !Year !Title !Record Company |- |1981 |'''杜麗莎''' |WEA |- |1983 |The Magic of Teresa Carpio |TV Records |- |1985 |'''何必放棄''' |TV Records |- |1986 |'''杜麗莎 Teresa Carpio''' |Warner Pioneer |- |1988 |'''杜麗莎 Teresa Carpio''' |TV Records/Current Records |- |2004 |Best of Times |Go East |- |2010 |I Still Remember |BMA Records |} === Duet === {| class="wikitable" !Year !Title !Record Company !Duet Artist |- |1978 |Teresa Carpio & George Lam |EMI |George Lam |- |2012 |Time After Time |Universal |Alan Tam |} === Live === {| class="wikitable" !Year !Title !Record Company |- |2001 |麗花皇宮 |Warner |- |2003 |HKPO & Teresa Carpio: DIVA |WSM |- |2004 |True Love |Go East |- |2005 |Always Lam In Concert |EEG |- |2007 |Lam and Teresa Live |EEG |- |2012 |Time After Time Live |Universal |} == Filmography == She has appeared in 13 movies in total, starting in 1984 with a lead role in [[開心鬼]] (Happy Ghost), where she also sang the theme song. She is more well known for her later movies where she often was famous for small roles that became extremely popular, such as 2003's [[六樓后座]] (Sixth Floor Rear Flat) where she sang part of 海闊天空 ([[Boundless Oceans, Vast Skies]]), accompanying herself on keyboards.{{Citation|last=herman lee|title=海闊天空- 六樓后座 by 杜麗莎|date=2009-07-01|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AN4307cjJss|accessdate=2017-02-26}} === Motion Pictures === {| class="wikitable" !Year !Title |- |1984 |[[cmn:開心鬼|開心鬼]] [[Happy Ghost]] |- |1985 |[[cmn:開心樂園|開心樂園]] Isle of Fantasy |- |1987 |靚妹正傳 No Regret |- |1988 |[http://hkmdb.com/db/movies/view.mhtml?id=7058&display_set=big5 黑心鬼] Three Wishes |- |1988 |火舞风云 Bet On Fire |- |1988 |[http://hkmdb.com/db/movies/view.mhtml?id=7111&display_set=big5 義膽紅唇] City War |- |1988 |好女十八嫁 18 Times |- |1989 |富貴再三逼人 It's A Mad Mad World 3 |- |1996 |嫲嫲帆帆 Age Of Miracles |- |2003 |行運超人 [[My Lucky Star (2003 film)|My Lucky Star]] |- |2003 |六樓后座 [[Truth or Dare: 6th Floor Rear Flat]] |- |2006 |寶貝計劃 [[Rob-B-Hood|Rob-B Hood]] |- |2012 |八星抱喜 [[All's Well, Ends Well 2012]] |} == Teaching == Carpio began teaching in 1991, when [[Sandy Lam]] came to her and asked her to teach her in preparation for her concerts at the Hong Kong Coliseum.{{Cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/article/443681/play-it-again-lam|title=Play it again, Lam|newspaper=South China Morning Post|access-date=2017-02-10|language=en}} After that, many other singers followed, names such as [[Sammi Cheng]], [[Wong Cho-lam|Wong Cho Lam]], [[Cecilia Cheung]], [[Joey Yung]], [[Gigi Leung]], [[Alex To]], [[Edmond Leung|Edmund Leung]], [[Twins (group)|Twins]], [[Jade Kwan]] and many more. She appeared on Hong Kong television as a judge and head vocal coach on season two of the singing competition ''[[The Voice (Hong Kong singing competition program)|The Voice]]''. == Major Concerts == {| class="wikitable" !Date !Concert !Venue !# of Performances !Solo/Joint/Guest !Special Guests |- |1983 |The Magic of Teresa Carpio |HK Coliseum |1 |Solo |None |- |2001 |La Fa Palace (麗花皇宮) |HK Polytechnic University |68 |Lead |N/A |- |2002 |HKPO & Teresa Carpio: DIVA |Cultural Centre |6 |Solo |[[T.V. Carpio|TV Carpio]] |- |2004 |True Love |HK Coliseum |2 |Solo |[[Jacky Cheung|Jacky Cheung (張學友)]], [[Gigi Leung|Gigi Leung (梁詠琪)]] |- |2005 |Always Lam |HK Coliseum |4 |Special Guest |N/A |- |2007 |Lam & Teresa |HK Coliseum |4 |With [[George Lam|George Lam (林子祥)]] |[[Lowell Lo|Lowell Lo (盧冠廷)]] |- |2010 |I Am A SInger |HK Coliseum |2 |Solo |[[T.V. Carpio|TV Carpio]], [[Wong Cho-lam|Wong Cho Lam (王祖藍)]] |- |2012 |Time After Time |HK Coliseum |9 |With [[Alan Tam|Alan Tam (譚詠麟)]] |None |} == ''[[Singer 2017]]'' == Prior to her appearance on ''Singer 2017'', on 20 August 2016, she appeared as a guest singer on the finals of [[:zh:跨界歌王|Crossover Singer]] 2016 for the performance of runner-up [[Wong Cho-lam|Wong Cho Lam]] (who sung a version of [[The Prayer (Celine Dion and Andrea Bocelli song)|The Prayer]].) {{Citation|last=第四季最强大脑|title=跨界歌王 第13期 20160820 王祖蓝, 杜丽莎 The Prayer|date=2016-08-20|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rl9Kb5doYiE|accessdate=2017-02-16}} As a result of her appearance, Carpio was selected as one of eight initial singers to compete in Hunan TV's [[Singer 2017]]. During her tenure, she told to the media that her participation was fueled by the fact that she was competing against another Hong Kong singer, [[Sandy Lam|Sandy Lam Yik-Lin]] (who she went on to win). Despite topping the singer's voting predictions (two 1st, one 2nd and one 3rd), she was eliminated on week five (2nd Knockout round) after receiving the lowest combined votes, largely due to finishing last on her prior week. Her elimination was not without controversy, with many fans questioning about the elimination.{{Cite news|url=http://www.twoeggz.com/news/3515194.html|title=相较歌手，更是艺术家的她在《歌手》惨遭淘汰，被疑有黑幕？|access-date=2017-02-11}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.hk01.com/%E9%9F%B3%E6%A8%82/71170/-%E6%AD%8C%E6%89%8B-%E6%9D%9C%E9%BA%97%E8%8E%8E%E7%9C%9F%E6%83%85%E6%B5%81%E9%9C%B2%E6%85%98%E9%81%AD%E6%B7%98%E6%B1%B0-%E7%B6%B2%E6%B0%91%E9%AC%A7%E7%88%86%E7%AF%80%E7%9B%AE%E7%B5%84|title=【歌手】杜麗莎真情流露慘遭淘汰　網民鬧爆節目組|last=彭嘉彬|website=香港01|language=en|access-date=2017-02-12}} After her Return performance on the week after elimination, Carpio later returned to the stage to participate the "Breakout Round", and at second place by a difference of three votes (0.15%) behind the top singer [[Li Jian (singer)|Li Jian]], she was one of the few singers to be reinstated from the competition. However, she was shortly eliminated again on the semi-finals a week later as one of the bottom two singers (the other was [[Julia Peng]]) receiving a lower count of votes. {| class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible" width="100%" style="text-align:center" |- align="center" style="background:#3399FF" | colspan="7" |

{{Infobox film | name = The Boy from Mercury | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | director = [[Martin Duffy]] | producer = Marina Hughes | writer = Martin Duffy | narrator = | starring = [[Rita Tushingham]]
[[Tom Courtenay]]
[[Hugh O'Conor]]
[[James Hickey (actor)|James Hickey]] | music = [[Stephen McKeon]] | cinematography = Seamus Deasy | editing = John Victor-Smith | studio = Blue Dahlia Productions | distributor = | released = 14 March 1996 | runtime = 87 minutes | country = Ireland | language = English }} '''''The Boy from Mercury''''' (1996) is a nostalgic [[Cinema of Ireland|Irish Film]], the first from writer and director [[Martin Duffy]]. The film concerns the science-fiction daydreams of a young boy in 1960 [[Dublin]]. Upon release, the film received international critical acclaim, and several awards, though was commercially unsuccessful. It was the first time actors [[Rita Tushingham]] and [[Tom Courtenay]] had appeared on screen together since ''[[Doctor Zhivago (1965 film)|Doctor Zhivago]]'' thirty years earlier. The film was also the debut of young Irish actor [[James Hickey (actor)|James Hickey]]. The book of the making of the film, [[The Road to Mercury]], written by the director, was released in 2006 by [[Ogma Press]]. ==External links== *{{imdb title|0115740}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boy from Mercury}} [[Category:Irish films]] [[Category:1996 films]] [[Category:1990s drama films]] [[Category:Films about children]] [[Category:Films about families]] [[Category:Films about school violence]] [[Category:Films set in 1960]] [[Category:Films set in Ireland]] [[Category:Irish drama films]] {{1990s-drama-film-stub}} {{Ireland-film-stub}}
